Rashida is the resident of a small city called Riawind. It is located in the Punjab province of Pakistan and famous for its religious festivals. Rashida is Christian and lives in the area of Ghouspura with her family. She is 50 years old and has spent more than 30 years of her life in this city. Rashida and her family are living in a four room brick house. She has two daughters and two sons. Only her youngest daughter, Saira, is getting an education currently while the others have finished by completing 10th standard. Saira reads in 9th standard. 

Rashida’s elder children are doing different kind of jobs to support the family financially. Her eldest son drives an auto rickshaw (three-wheeled motor vehicle). Her second son works in a factory for a small income and her elder daughter is a school teacher.  

Her husband is also a rickshaw driver. He works for fulltime to meet the financial needs of the family and to put three meals on the table.  Rashida is a very caring lady. She stays at home, manages the household chores and takes care of her family.  She has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband who wants to repair his rickshaw. 

Her husband is very confident that he can be work better with a repaired rickshaw and earn a very good income because he will be able to work for longer hours.

loans.use: Repair a rickshaw

loans.name: Chen

texts.en: Chen S., 30, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She is employed at a local garment factory for an income of $3 US per day. Her husband is an electrician, earning an income of $4 per day.  S. is requesting a loan of $1,200 to help build her brother’s house. In the future, she would like to send her children to good schools.  This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: help build her brother's house

loans.name: Van

texts.en: Van A., 44, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. A. and her husband sell hand-made brooms for an income of $3 US each per day.  A. is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase more brooms to resell. In the future, she would like to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy more brooms to sell

loans.name: Zubaida

texts.en:
Zubaida lives in the area of Ghouspura, which is a small colony in the city of Riawind. Riawind is located in the Punjab province of Pakistan and is famous for its dairy products and agriculture. Zubaida is 37 and has 6 children. Unfortunately none of them could get an education due to the family's poor financial condition.  

Zubaida got married to M. B. who is attached to the profession of selling milk. He has four buffalos at his home which produce milk for him. Zubaida helps her husband in getting the milk from the buffalos by getting up at 5 o’clock in morning every day. Then they both put the milk in milk-jars and her husband goes to different milk shops to sell it.  Zubaida takes care of the cattle by providing them food and water as well. She makes sure that their place is clean to avoid catching any diseases.

She has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband who wants to buy another buffalo. He thinks that by purchasing another buffalo his income will be increased by selling an increased quantity milk to his customers.  Zubaida has been a client of Asasah for the last 5 years and has proved herself a responsible client who never misses any meeting and pays installments on time.

loans.use: Purchase another buffalo for dairy business

loans.name: Mark

texts.en:
Mark O. is 52 years old and married to three wives; they have sixteen children who are all school-going children and are under 18 years. They live in a rural area called Ngiya in Siaya district. 

Mark is a farmer and normally sells farm produce to earn a living. He is applying for a loan from Kadet Ltd to buy “My Sunshine Box” which will help him in lighting his home. Mark’s children use lanterns for lighting and this is too cumbersome for them. They struggle a lot when doing their homework at night. Mark has serviced a loan before with KADET LTD, and he repaid it well without any difficulties.

He hopes and waits for the day when electricity will be installed in his rural home.

loans.use: Buy "My Sunshine Box"

loans.name: Keko Ole

texts.en:
For the last three years, Keko has been rearing animals and selling them during peak season at a profit.  He is 36 years old, married to Hannah Mulejo, and they have two children.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to buy 10 goats and five sheep which he will rear and sell later at a profit.

Keko also hopes to have an animal farm where he will live with his family as he rears the animals.

loans.use: To buy 10 goats and  five  sheep which he will rear and sell later at a profit.

loans.name: Cheung

texts.en: Cheung S., 50, is a Khmer traditional doctor in Kampong Cham province. Since 2004, he has been treating people's illnesses and selling traditional medicines and is able to make US$ 2 in profit each day. He is a widower with one daughter, who is already married but still living at home with him. His daughter has a business weaving silk cloth and makes US$ 1 per day. Cheung S. is asking for a loan of US$ 400 to purchase beads and other weaving materials for his daughter.

loans.use: To purchase beads and other weaving materials

loans.name: Bayarbileg

texts.en:
Bayarbileg G. is a 53-year-old widow who lives with her two children in the Central province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her daughter is a student and her son attends a local middle school. 

Bayarbileg has been living in her town for 21 years and now she operates a clothes-making business with the help of her daughter. Bayarbileg worked as a quality examiner of DaDi Mongol, a local garment industry from  2004 to 2008 and since 2009, she has owned her own small tailoring shop where she not only sews traditional Mongolian-style clothing, but also sews European-style clothing in cooperation with a tailor.  

Because she has gained a lot of experience, she knows what her customers want and how much they are willing to pay for her quality clothing. She wants one day to upgrade her old sewing machine to a newer, more sophisticated one so that she can experiment with more elaborate designs in her clothing. Bayarbileg is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more fabrics and other materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more fabrics and other materials

loans.name: Nem

texts.en: Nem S., 63, is a motor-taxi driver in the local market of Kampong Cham province. His wife is a farm worker, growing rice and vegetables. On average, she is able to make less than US$ 1 per day. This couple has one child who is employed as a worker. Nem S. would like to take out a loan of US$ 700 to purchase another motorbike so that his son can operate a motor-taxi as he does.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for his son to operate a motor-taxi

loans.name: Dosbol

texts.en:
Dosbol D. is 36 years old and lives with his wife and three children in a ger--a traditional nomadic housing tent--in the Bayan-Ulgiy province of western Mongolia. His elder two children attend a local middle school and the youngest son goes to a local kindergarten. His wife takes care of their children.

Dosbol operates a taxi service between the countryside and the capital of the province. He started his business in 1992 and after several years in business, he was able to afford to buy a larger, more reliable automobile. But the van he has purchased was a disadvantageous one that  requires too much petrol which has made it hard for him to manage his business successfully and make a profit. 

Dosbol is still operating his transportation business  but supplements his  service earnings by transporting raw materials such as sheepskins, goat skins and wool and coal from the countryside to the province center. He works very hard to provide for his family. He says, “My only wish is to support my children's education and have them become good people.” 

Dosbol is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase tires for his automobile and a large amount of coal for his business.

loans.use: To purchase tires for his automobile and coal to transport

loans.name: Eoung

texts.en: Eoung P., 52, is a widow who lives with three children in Takeo province. She buys and sells silk cloth and typically makes US$ 5 each day. She is also supported by one of her children who works in a garment factory. Eoung P. is asking for a loan of US$ 500 to purchase more silk cloth to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more silk cloth to sell.

loans.name: Muqqadas

texts.en:
Muqqadas lives in a small city called Riwind with her husband and family. She is a housewife. She stays at her 3-room brick house and takes care of her family. She is the mother of three daughters and a son, all of whom are getting their education. She is 36 years old and has spent all of her life in Riwind. She married M. H. and moved to her husband’s home 12 years ago. It is also located in Riwind. 

Her husband has a business renting out cars to earn his daily income. He has two cars and his business is doing well currently. He purchased these cars on installment by receiving loans from Asasah. 

Muqqadas also invested in the purchasing of the cars, money which she earned from her sewing business. She is excellent at her work. She gets orders from her neighborhood clients who give her good money for her work. 

She has applied for a loan for the sixth time from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount her husband will pay off the remaining installments of his cars. Muqqadas is very confident because by paying the remaining installments, the cars will become her husband’s property and he will be able to work in a better manner.

loans.use: To pay off the remaining installments of cars for rent-a-car business

loans.name: Suon

texts.en: Suon L., 45, is a widow who lives with two children and her father in Takeo province. Since 2007, she has been selling cakes and is able to make about US$ 1.50 in profit each day.  Her children are garment factory workers, making US$ 2 each per day. Suon L. is asking for a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Mrs. Lina Keut Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan includes 11 people who live in Roleang Kreul village in Takeo province. All the members will use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their standard of living in this current year. Mrs. Lina K. is the village bank president, selected by the other members. She was born in 1981. She is a fruit and vegetable seller in the local market where she is able to earn a large profit to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Ravy Vut, is a taxi driver. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand. So Mrs. Lina K. is requesting a loan to buy more vegetables to sell. Through this activity, they support three children who all attend school and help their parents’ businesses.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Lum

texts.en:
Lum S., 41, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean temples. S. is employed breaking mountain rock in pieces for an income of USD 1.50 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 2.50 per day. 

S. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase a new motorbike. In the future, she would like to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S.'s husband appears in the photograph because S. was not available.

loans.use: buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Un

texts.en:
Un S., 26, is married and lives with two young children in the Takeo Province. Since 2003, she has been working in a garment factory. She is able to make about $3 USD per day. Her husband is a taxi driver. He earns $5 USD a day.

Un S. would like to take out a loan of $800 USD to purchase a motorbike to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Huoch's Group

texts.en:
Four people are making up a group loan. Mrs. Huoch S., age 62, is the leader of this group loan, having been selected by its four members who all live in Spean Daek village, in Kandal province. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their different businesses.

Mrs. Huoch S. is owns a small general store while her husband, Mr. Sanh Thy, is a fisherman. With both of these occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. In order to support her husband's fishing, Mrs. Huoch S. will use the loan, that she has requested from AMK, to buy fishing supplies for fishing. This couple has two children who are laborers.

loans.use: To buy fishing supplies for fishing.

loans.name: Preung

texts.en:
Preung S., 36, is a professional silk weaver. She makes $2 USD each day. She lives and works in the Takeo Province. She is married and has four children to support who live at home. Her husband, Thouk Nov, makes approximately $2.50 USD every day, working in construction.

Preung S. would like a loan of $1,000 USD to purchase more silk.

loans.use: To purchase more silk.

loans.name: Bun

texts.en:
Bun S., 23, sells palm sugar in the local market of his Takeo Province. On average, he is able to make $4 USD of profit a day. His wife is a garment factory worker, making $2 USD per day. This couple has one young child living at home to support. Bun S. is now living with his mother.

Bun S. is asking for a loan of $350 USD to purchase more palm sugar to sell at the market.

(Bun S. and his wife were not available for picture so Bun S.'s mother is pictured instead.)

loans.use: To purchase more palm sugar.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy pig food and piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Yasmeen

texts.en:
Yasmeen lives in a three room brick house in Riawind, Pakistan. It is a small city near Lahore and famous for its dairy products and agricultural industry.

Yasmeen is 23 years old, married to E. A.. She has two children: 4-year-old, Iram, and 1-year-old Ali. Both are very young and have not started to attend school yet.

Her husband operates a grocery shop in the market. He sells rice, cooking oil and other household grocery items to earn a living for his family. He has 8 years of experience in this business.

Yasmeen supports her family with her sewing business. She is good in her art and gets regular orders and fulfills them on a timely basis. She has a good reputation among her customers for her quality work.

She has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband who wants to improve his grocery business. With the loan amount he will buy groceries in bulk to increase the stock of his shop and income as well.

Yasmeen is very hopeful that this investment will help her husband to improve his business' condition.

Yasnmeen is in her 4th loan cycle. In previous years, she has proven herself a responsible client who has always paid loan installments on time.

loans.use: To purchase groceries for her grocery shop

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Chan U., 40, is married and resides with her husband and six children in Takeo Province, Cambodia. The area is well-known for Pre-Angkorean Temples. 

U. sells groceries and snacks for an income of  $1 USD per day, and is pictured above at her grocery store. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of $2.50 USD per day. U. and her husband are also farmers, and the rice they grow from the field is for feeding their family.

U. is requesting a loan of $600 USD to purchase cows to help plow the rice field. In the future, she would like to repair her house. 

This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy cows to help plow the rice field

loans.name: Sot

texts.en: Sot T., 31, has a business selling brooms at the local market of her Takeo province and earns approximately US$1 a day. Her husband, pictured here, stays at home making brooms. The brooms are made from a type of long grass which grows in the forest. Both husband and wife know how to make brooms, having learned from their neighbors, and began their business in 2000. The couple have two children. Sot T. is asking for a loan of US$800 to purchase a motorbike to transport brooms to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Touch

texts.en: Touch A., 50, is married and lives with three of her children in the Takeo province. She and her husband are farmers who typically make about US$1 a day and are supported by two of their children working in a garment factory. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into what is a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Touch A. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US$700 to purchase fertilizer. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer.

loans.name: Savann's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. SaV. Y., age 54, is the leader of this group loan, having been selected by its four members who all live in Kaoh Kaev village in Kandal province. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their different businesses.

Mrs. SaV. Y. is a pig breeder at home and, aside from pig breeding, she also sells sour cabbage in the local market. With both of these occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. In order to support this sour cabbage business, Mrs. SaV. Y. will use the loan to buy vegetables to make sour cabbage for selling. Mrs. SaV. Y. is widow with two children. One is a construction worker and one is student in the local school.

loans.use: To buy vegetables to make sour cabbage to sell.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Chea C., 24, is married and resides with her husband and child in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean Temples. C. and her husband are employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of USD 2.5 each per day. In addition, C.'s mother weaves traditional Cambodian silk at home. C. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a new motorbike for the commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. C.'s mother appears in the photograph because C. is at the factory.

loans.use: Buy a new motorbike to commute to work

loans.name: Vorn

texts.en: Mrs. Vorn S., 53, is married to Ou Chorn, 52, and the couple earn a living by cultivating crops. They currently have six children, two of whom are married and live separately, while the other four are single. In addition to their farming work, Vorn S. produces cakes to sell to her nearby villagers, who eat them as a snack food. The coming rainy season is good for growing. However, Vorn S. doesn’t have any farming supplies to use on her field. Thus, she has asked for a loan to use towards buying fertilizer, insecticide and crop seed for planting.

loans.use: To use towards buying fertilizer, insecticide and crop seed for planting

loans.name: Rukhsana

texts.en:
Rukhsana lives with her family in Raiwind, which is famous for its agriculture industry. Raiwind is a small city of Punjab province, Pakistan and located near Lahore. Rukhsana lives in a three-room brick house with her family. She is 28 years old and has two children, three-year-old Zunaira and one-year-old Anil. Both are very young and not yet old enough for school. 

Rukhsana is involved in the embroidery business. She has contracts with different boutiques for whom she makes embroidered clothes and earns income for her family. She is good at her art and gets regular orders. She earns approximately 5-6,000 PKRs every month, which has become a big financial source. Her husband works in the timber selling business. His business is going well, earning him regular income. He has been doing this business for over ten years.  

Rukhsana has applied for a loan for the third time from Asasah for her husband’s business. The loan amount will help her husband to buy timber in bulk in order to fulfill larger orders in time. Rukhsana is confident that this investment will bring positive change to her husband’s business and that he will be able to improve his income. She is a very responsible loan user of Asasah. She has always paid installments on time and attends meetings regularly. 

Note: In this photo, the lady seated next to her in the blue shawl is her sister-in-law and is helping her with the embroidery business.

loans.use: Purchase timbers for selling

loans.name: Pen

texts.en:
Pen P., 41, is a weaver of traditional Cambodian silk, an activity that earns her an income of USD 2.5 per day. Her husband (pictured here because P. was not available) is a construction worker, earning an income of USD 2 per day. Their eldest child is currently employed at a local garment factory and earns an income of USD 2 per day to help cover the family expenses.  

P. is requesting a loan of USD 700 in order to purchase more raw silk so that she can produce more silk products. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits toward necessary repairs to her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.
 
P. resides with her husband and five children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for its pre-Angkorean temples.

loans.use: To buy more raw silk in order to produce silk products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy ingredients for her cakes

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Mrs. S. is a 73-year-old farmer who lives in Kompong Tom Province.  S. is married to Mr. Yeab, age 57, who works as a laborer in the construction sector. This couple currently has three children (two boys and one daughter) who are no longer in school and are working at a various jobs.  S. doesn’t have her own vehicle so the family transportation is limited. With the loan she is requesting, she plans to buy a motorcycle. The loan will provide the family with an asset because of which they will be able to reduce the cost of hiring taxis. Mrs. S. was not available when the photo taken, so her daughter is pictured instead.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Mr. Hon Hang Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mr. Hon H. is a village bank president who is 29 years old. He was selected by fifteen people who make up a village bank loan. Each member of the group will use their portion of the loan for various ways to support their family located in Kampong Luong village, in Takeo province. Mr. Hon H. and his wife, Mrs. Chan Net Touch, are farmers who own a one-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to rice to sell to support their family. Mr Hon H. is also a fisherman, while his wife is a pig breeder. His problem is that his wife’ piglets are too small to sell, but he did not have money to support them. So to improve this condition, Mr. Hon H. is asking for a loan to buy pig food. He is a father of three children, one of whom is enrolled in a local school, while the others are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy pig food.

loans.name: Sourng

texts.en: Sourng S., 36, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean Temples. She is employed at a local garment factory for an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 3 per day.  S. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a tuk tuk (auto rickshaw) to expand her husband’s business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a tuk tuk.

loans.name: Rani

texts.en:
Rani is a 56 year-old woman who is still very active for her age. She lives in a small city called Riawind.  Riawind is located in the Punjab province of Pakistan and is famous for its religious festivals.  

Rani is married to M. S. who runs a grocery shop in a local market. He started this business five years ago and during this time he has faced both hard and good times.  However, he has overcome problems with strong beliefs and struggle.   

Rani is the mother of five children: four sons and one daughter.  All of them are illiterate because they couldn’t get education due to financial crises. Things are different now as all of them, except her daughter, do different kind of jobs to support the family.  

Rani’s eldest son sells timbers. The next eldest works in a motor workshop. The third son has a business selling mobile phones in  a shop in the market and the youngest son is an employee in a factory on a monthly wage.   

Rani herself is involved in the milk-selling business. She has a buffalo at her home which produces 6-8kg milk everyday and she sells it to her neighborhood clients.  She sells 1kg for 45 PKRs and, on average, she earns 360 PKRs everyday.   

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan amount he will buy groceries in bulk which will enable him to fulfill the needs of his customers and to earn a better  income.

Note: In this photo, Rani is standing with one of her sons in her husband's grocery shop.

loans.use: To purchase groceries.

loans.name: Mr. Vutha Uk Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mr. Vutha U., born in 1961, has been selected as a village bank president by fourteen people, making up a village bank loan, located in Kampong LU. village in Takeo province. All of the members will use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their current businesses. Mr. Vutha U. and his wife, Mrs. Khorn Doeun, are farmers. They own a one and a half-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. Mr. Vutha U. is also a fisherman who can earn some money by selling fish. His problem is that his fishing supplies are too old to use. So to improve this condition, Mr. Vutha U. is applying for a loan to buy fishing nets and resin to fix his fishing boat. He is a father of three children who are all helping in their parents’ businesses.

loans.use: To buy fishing nets and resin to fix his fishing boat.

loans.name: La's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. La O., age 41, is the village bank president, selected by the eight members of this group loan. The members are located in Svay Pang Ankrang village in Kandal province. Each member of this village loan will use their portion of the loan to support their different businesses. 

Mrs. La O. and her husband, Mr. Sokhom Sam, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice. Aside from farming, Mrs. La O. is also a vegetable seller in the local market. With both of these occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. Mrs. La O. is now requesting a loan to buy a motorbike to transport her vegetables to sell. This couple has three children; one is a laborer, one sells fruit for a salary, and one is a student in the local school.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to transport her vegetables

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina F. is a 52-year old married woman who supports her family by operating two businesses:  farming and rice reselling. She lives in Purok 1, Brgy. Inalad, Siaton, Negros Oriental. Since 2002, she has been a member of Kiva partner NWTF-Project Dungganon and has improved her living condition with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her farming and rice businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 8,000. 

Regina is now borrowing PHP 10,000 so that she can fund her farm operations .   This will be her 17th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Regina aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund operations.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Heang

texts.en: Heang S., 36, is married and lives with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean Temples. She sells sweet potatoes for an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband is a farmer and a traditional musician, earning an income of USD 2 per day.  S. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase cows to help plough the rice field. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S.'s husband appears in the photograph because S. was not available.

loans.use: To buy cows to help plough the field.

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Sim P., 46, along with her life partner, Mr. Thy, 51, earns a living by cultivating crops on farmland that they own, located near their village. In addition to her farming work, Sim P. makes porridge and sells it to her neighbors and fellow villagers for additional income. 

The irrigation system is located a considerable distance away from Sim P.’s farm, so she has always faced difficulty when it comes to watering her crops. To solve this problem, Sim P. has requested a loan that will be used to buy a machine that will pump water for her crops.      

The couple has four children, one of whom is married. One of their children works as a construction worker and two are secondary teachers.

loans.use: To buy a machine that will pump water for her crops

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie S. lives in Purok 1 Yardahan, Barangay Bal-os in Basay, Negros Oriental. She and her husband earn their living through fishing and fish vending.  Her husband Beltasar, age 67, is a fisherman.  They have 4 children ranging in age from 2 to 17 years old. 

Rosalie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rosalie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 helped her increase their family income to PHP 22,000,  uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 17th loan, she is requesting PHP 15,000 which she will use to purchase a new engine for their fishing boat so that her husband could continue with his fishing activities and Rosalie will have fish to sell. They are both working very hard to send all their children to school. Rosalie S. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To buy an engine for the fishing boat.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Veronica M. is 28 years old and has two children ages 4 and 7. She is a widow and the sole provider for her family. Veronica sells cereals and potatoes to the local residents in Shanzu, Mombasa. She has been in this business for two years now and it has been successful.  This is Veronica's first loan request from KADET and she will use it to buy more cereal and potatoes for her store.

loans.use: To purchase assorted cereals and potatoes.

loans.name: Sam Aul's Group

texts.en:
A group of four people in Andoung Kien village of Takeo province has selected Mrs. Sam Aul L. as their leader. The group members will use their portion of the loan to support their respective businesses. 

Mrs. Sam Aul L. is a tailor in the local village, and she earns enough money to support her family. She wants to expand her tailoring business, which is going on well. So to improve her business, Mrs. Sam Aul L. is seeking a loan to buy fabric to design clothes for her customers. Her husband, Mr. Nang Be, is a motor bicycle repairman, and is also a farmer who owns a plot of land where he cultivates rice for sale to support his family. The couple does not have a child.

loans.use: To buy fabric to design clothes for her customers

loans.name: Pheng

texts.en: Pheng R., age 52, is widowed and resides with her four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She produces cow ties (leashes and harnesses) to sell for a daily income of about USD 6.  Pheng is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase more nylon to produce ties. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more nylon for producing cow ties.

loans.name: Antonina

texts.en:
Antonina A. lives in Barangay Pasil in Santander, Cebu. She and her husband Juanito earn their living by operating a pig fattening business. They have 4 adult children. Antonina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 12 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Antonina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty through her hard work. 

Her previous loan of PHP 3000 generated a monthly profit of PHP 2500, improving the family standard of living.  This time, for her 13th loan, she requests PHP 10000, which she will use to purchase feed and more piglets to raise. Antonina A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To buy more feed and piglets.

loans.name: Benso 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe Benso 1 sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans et en moyenne  3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Maban, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités  hivernales. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont le petit mil, l’arachide et le haricot. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne et tous les deux prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, WASSA T. compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de main d’œuvre pour entretenir environs 1,5 hectare de petit mil et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Dioïla après les récoltes à une clientèle composée de revendeurs. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 75.000FCFA environ en fin de campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Benso 1 group are married women on average 39 years old with three children. Most live in polygamous families in Maban, one of the villages belonging to the Dioïla Prefecture in the Koulokoro region, part of the 2nd administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to better organise their winter activities. Their cash crops are millet, peanuts and beans. This is their third farming loan and the two preceding ones have been duly repaid. With this new loan Wassa T. intends to buy seeds and fertilizer, small farming equipment and pay laborers to cultivate approximately 1.5 hectares (3.7 acres) of millet and peanuts. After harvesting the crops are sold in Dioïla to mainly retail merchants. She hopes to reach average earnings of 75,000 FCFA by the end of the farming season.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Seeds and fertilizer, labor costs and small farming equipment.

loans.name: Bendetta

texts.en: Bendetta S. is a 47-year-old married mother of eight children. She lives in Mshomoroni, Mombasa with her family and has been operating a retail shop for the past three years. Bendetta is requesting her first loan from KADET in order to purchase sugar, rice, and maize flour for her retail shop. Her main clients are the area residents. In the future, she hopes to own  a big wholesale shop in Mombasa.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, rice, and maize flour.

loans.name: Yean

texts.en: Mrs. Yean O., aged 52, lives in the Province of Kompong Tom in Cambodia, where she makes a living by raising pigs and crops. Since 1979, she has run this business with great success, and it has provided her with an income to raise her standard of living. She is the good mother of four children: three are building laborers and the other one is a local farmer. Her husband assists her in the business. Pig-raising is the main source of family income, and Yean O. hopes to improve it by requesting a Kiva loan to buy more piglets for her pigpen.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for her pigpen.

loans.name: Trinidad

texts.en:
Trinidad M. is a widow  who lives in, Brgy. Pasil, Santander, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  a sari-sari (general) store and a pig-fattening business. Trinidad joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 10 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Trinidad has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. 

Her previous loan of PHP 19500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10000, raising the family's standard of living. This time, for her 11th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 19500, which she intends to use to buy additional groceries to sell in her sari sari store so that she can continue to save up for the future and for emergencies. Trinidad M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase of more products to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sao

texts.en: Sao S., 38, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She sells rice and vegetables for an income of USD 4.3 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of USD 3 per day.  S. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase more rice to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy more rice to resell

loans.name: Khorn's Group

texts.en:
A group of four people from Chrouy Poun village in Takeo province are asking for a loan, and have selected Mrs. Khorn M. as their group leader. The group members will use their individual portions of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Khorn M., born in 1966, is a farmer who owns a two point six-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice for sale to support her family, while her husband, Mr. Chan Ben, is the village chief. Her problem is that her field has infertile soil. So to improve the quantity and quality of rice production, Mrs. Khorn M. is requesting a loan manly to buy fertilizers and use rest of the loan to hire a plow machine to plow her field. She has four children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the other two are attending school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers

loans.name: Benso 2 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe Benso 2 sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent majoritairement dans des familles polygames à Maban, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités hivernales. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres le petit mil, l’arachide, le sésame et le haricot. 
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, AWA D. compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de main d’œuvre entretenir environs 1,6 hectare d’arachide.
La production est vendue au niveau de la ville de  Dioïla et Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes venant des grandes villes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 70.000FCFA environ en fin de  campagne.
texts.en:
The ten member of the group "Benso 2" are married women averaging 35 years of age and three children. The members live for the most part in polygamous families in Maban, a village in Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of better organizing their wintertime work. The crops grown include pearl millet, peanuts, sesame, and beans. The group members are on their third farm loan. All their previous loans have been repaid. With this new loan, AWA D. intends to buy supplies and sundry equipment and to cover the cost of labor for maintaining about 1.6 hectares of peanuts. After the harvest, the produce is sold in the cities of Dioïla and Massigui to a customer base composed of men and women from major cities. The group members plan on making an average profit of about 70,000 francs CFA at the end of the planting season.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Farm supplies, labor, and equipment

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda D. is a 41-year old married woman who supports her family by operating a general store. She lives in Prk. Paliya, Brgy. Busogon, San Remegio, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She earns an average monthly income of PHP 6000. 

Erlinda is now borrowing PHP 15000 to purchase more stock for her general store. This will be her 5th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Erlinda aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: purchase of more stock to sell

loans.name: Nhim

texts.en: Nhim P. is 33 years old and lives with five of her children in the Kampong Cham province. She and her husband are farmers and she also weaves baskets to sell at the market, while her husband sells palm sugar. The couple is able to make about US$5 each day. Nhim P. is asking for a loan of US$1000 to expand her farmland and also buy fertilizer.

loans.use: To expand her farmland and buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Theophile

texts.fr: Théophile T. est un homme de 38  ans qui a été à Rubavu ex prefecture de Gisenyi, il vit actuellement en province de Kigali  district de Kicukiro, capital du Rwanda. Il est marié, il a quatre enfants dont le plus âgée a 14 ans et le moins âgée a 4 ans  tous vont à l’école il est salarié dans une entreprise fabriquant les matériaux métalliques. Avec le prêt il veut installer l’électricité dans sa maison ainsi que l’eau. Les épargnes continuelles lui permettent de la survie de sa famille et il acheter une moto pour utiliser comme taxi pour augmenter les revenues et la capacité financière de la famille. Dans l’avenir il veut acheter une voiture, et planifier pour le bon futur de  sa famille.
texts.en:
Théophile T. is a 38-year old man who was [born] in Rubavu, in the ex-prefecture of Gisenyi. He currently lives in the province of Kigali (Rwanda's capital), in the district of Kicukiro. He is married and has four children ranging from 4 to 14 years of age. The children all go to school. He is an employee in a metal manufacturing factory. With this loan he would like to have electricity and running water installed in his house. He has been constantly saving money in order to be able to provide for his family, and he [wants] to buy a motorcycle and use it as a taxi, to increase his income and the financial resources of his family. In the future he would like to purchase a car and be able to plan for a better future for his family.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Installing electricity and running water in his house

loans.name: Kisaakua Ole

texts.en:
Kisaakua has been buying, rearing, and selling animals in Naivasha town for the last 4 years.  He is 47 years old, married to Susan Koisaba, and they have two children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to use the cash to buy goats and sheep which he rears and sell later at a profit.

Kisaakua also wants to start cultivating his piece of farmland and plant wheat for commercial purposes.

loans.use: To buy goats and sheep for resale

loans.name: Shahnaaz's Group

texts.en:
Shahnaaz lives in a historic city of Pakistan called Lahore. Lahore is the capital city of Punjab province and the second largest city in Pakistan, also known for its history, gardens, culture and food. 

Shahnaaz lives in a 2-room brick house with her family. She is 46 years old and has been living in Lahore for the past 30 years. She is a mother of 2 sons. Her husband works in the government sector as a government employee and she helps support her family by selling clothes. She has been doing this work for the past 5 years. She buys clothes from “Azam market" and "AnarkA.,” two famous cloth markets of Lahore. 

She mainly sells clothes to her neighboring customers but now she wants to sell her clothes to different clothes shops. Therefore, she has applied for a loan from Asasah. With the loan amount she will purchase clothes in bulk of different varieties which will increase her chances of making better income and selling more clothes to the clothes shops. 

This is first time Shahnaaz has applied for a loan from any MFI. She hopes that it will be a good experience for her.

loans.use: Purchase clothes for resale

loans.name: Soam

texts.en: Soam K., 43, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean temples. She sells groceries for an income of USD 5 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of USD 5 per day.  K. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase more groceries to stock the store. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Benso 3 Group

texts.fr:
Benso 3 est un regroupement de 10 femmes mariées ayant en moyenne 42 ans,  3 enfants et vivant dans des familles polygames à Maban, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités hivernales. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont le petit mil, l’arachide, le pois de terre et le haricot. 
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, ARATOU MAMADOU D. compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de  main d’œuvre pour entretenir environs 1,5  hectare petit mil et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Dioïla et Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 70.000FCFA en fin de  campagne.
texts.en:
Benso 3 is a group of ten married women who average 42 years of age, have three children each and live in polygamous families in Maban, one of the villages in the prefecture of Dioïla, in the region of Koulikoro, Mali's second administrative region. They are collaborating with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the goal of better organising their winter activities. They grow pearl millett, peanuts, peas and beans. They are on their third farming loan and the previous loans have been repaid in full. With this new loan, Aratou Mamadou Dembelle is planning on buying intrants and small materials as well as paying the labor costs of maintaining around one and a half hectares of pearl millet and peanuts. The produce is sold after the harvest in the towns of Dioïla and Massiqui to a customer base made up of men and women. She is counting on making a profit of 70.000FCFA at the end of the season.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Intrants, labor and small materials

loans.name: Eam

texts.en: Eam T., 46, is married with two children living at home in Kampong Cham province. She sells vegetables and fruit, typically making US$ 5 each day. Her husband, pictured here, is a taxi driver. Her husband typically makes about US$ 10 each day. Eam T. would like a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase a car for her husband to operate as a taxi.

loans.use: To purchase a car to use as a taxi

loans.name: Hodari Group

texts.fr: Mawazo Bakulu C. est présidente actuel du groupe Hodari pour son nouveau cycle de crédit, elle est âgée de 44 ans, mariée, mère de 11 enfants. Son mari est tailleur couturier. Tous ces 10 enfants vont à l’école sauf le cadet qui a encore 3 ans. Elle fait le petit commerce de vente de souliers et vêtements divers. Elle n’a pas un lieu précis, elle vend de manière ambulatoire, elle fait de crédits aux divers preneurs de ses produits. Elle commence avec le 50$ de crédit de Hekima, après avoir connu un vol de son capital au niveau de Kampala (Ouganda, elle rentabilisa ce crédit, et actuellement elle inspire  au crédit de 800$. Ce crédit sera affecté dans le business de vente de vêtements. Comme défis majeur, elle est encore incapable de louer une chambre (boutique) pour une exposition de ses produits. Elle souhaite dans le jour avenir, acheter une seconde parcelle et y construire confortablement. En outre elle souhaiterait que ses enfants étudient confortablement. La cliente Mawazo Bakulu C. remercie Hekima pour le crédit qu’elle reçoit sans aucune garantie.
texts.en:
C. Mawazo Bakulu is the current president of the Hodari group for the new loan cycle. She is 44 years old, married, and a mother to 11 children. Her husband is a tailor. All of her children attend school except for the youngest, age 3. C. has a small business selling miscellaneous footwear and clothing. Having no fixed location to carry on her activities, she goes on the road to sell her goods, and allows her customers to buy on credit. She received a $50 loan from Hekima after being robbed of her capital in Kampala, Uganda. She managed to achieve profitability and is currently seeking an $800 loan, which she will use in her clothing retail business. Being unable to rent space to display her merchandise remains a major hurdle. In the future, she wants to buy a second plot of land to build a comfortable home. She also wants her children to receive proper schooling. As a member of the micro-finance institution, C. wishes to thank Hekima for granting her a loan without any guarantees.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase of 30 pairs of pants, 50 sets (blouse and skirt), 40 blouses, and 20 children’s outfits

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina  S. is a 39-year-old married woman who supports her family by selling a variety of products: school supplies, cosmetics, toys, etc.  She lives in Purok Bagong Pag-asa, Brgy. Antipuluan, Narra, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her retail business,  she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 55,000. 

Gina  is now borrowing PHP 29,500 so that she  can  purchase more stock to sell.   This will be her 21st loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500, which she paid off well within its term was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Gina  aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Chrek

texts.en: Mrs. Chrek M. has had a farming job since she was single. She is now married with two children; one is already married and has started new home, while another one is single and works. Chrek M. learned farming skills from her grandparents, and her husband works in the farm fields frequently alongside her. Growing crops is an annual job with which she has had great success. To reduce her hard physical labor on the field, Chrek M. is applying for a loan to buy a cow to help with plowing the farmland.

loans.use: To buy a cow to help with plowing the farmland

loans.name: Chamroeun's Group

texts.en:
Mr. ChamroeU. S., 43, is the village bank president selected by 11 members of this group loan. The group members are located in Trapeang Chak village in Kandal province. Each group member will use their portion of the loan to support their individual businesses.  
Mr. ChamroeU. S. and his wife, Mrs. S. Kong Lai, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice for a living. In order to support this farm, Mr. ChamroeU. S. will use the loan to buy fertilizers, pesticides and to pay for farming laborers to cultivate rice. Aside from being a farmer, he is also construction worker who receives a small salary to support his family. The couple has four children: two are seamstresses in the garment factory, one is a student in the local school, and the youngest is only a year old.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide and to pay for farming laborers to cultivate rice

loans.name: Rebeka

texts.en: Rebeka T. is currently in the business of running a retail shop and the goods she sells include: sugar, tea leaves, soap, cartons of salt, and many others. She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of rice and sugar to sell.  Rebeka is 32 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent out.

loans.use: stock more bags of rice and sugar to sell

loans.name: Benso 4 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  membres du groupe Benso 4 sont des femmes mariées qui ont en moyenne 41 ans,  4 enfants et vivent dans des familles polygames à Maban, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités  hivernales. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont le petit mil, l’arachide et le haricot. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, ADJA D. compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de main d’œuvre pour entretenir environs 1,2 hectare de petit mil et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Dioïla et Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée  de revendeurs et de consommateurs. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 55.000FCFA environ en fin de campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of Benso 4 group are married women who average 41 years of age, have four children each and live in polygamous families in Maban, one of the villages in the prefecture of Dioïla, in the region of Koulikoro, Mali's second administrative region. They are collaborating with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the goal of better organising their winter activities. They grow pearl millett, peanuts and beans. They are on their third farming loan and the previous loans have been repaid in full. With this new loan, Adja Dembelle is planning on buying intrants and small materials as well as paying the labor costs of maintaining around 1.2 hectares of pearl millet and peanuts. The produce is sold in the towns of Dioïla and Massiqui after the harvest to a customer base made up of retailers and consumers. They are counting on making an average profit of around 55.000FCFA at the end of the season.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Labor, sowing, fertilizers, weedkiller, hoeing and small materials

loans.name: Nourn

texts.en:
Nourn P., 42, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She sells snacks and cakes in front of a school for an income of $3 US per day. 

Her husband (pictured) is a recycler, earning an income of $10 per day.  P. is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase a motorbike to transport recyclable materials. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. P.’s husband appears in the photograph because P. is not available.

loans.use: buy a motorbike to transport recyclable materials

loans.name: Mrs. Phorn Nget Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of 16 people who live in Tuol Pongro village in Takeo province. Mrs. P. N. has been selected as the village bank president by other members. Each group member will use their portion of the loan for a different purpose. 

P. N., born in 1972, owns a general store in the local village and is also a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. On Sam, is a farmer who owns one-and-half hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to support his family. Her piglets are too small to sell, and she does not have enough money to support them. So to improve the breeding of pigs, Mrs. P. N. is seeking a loan to buy pig food and use the rest of the loan to buy pesticides. She has two children who are attending school.

loans.use: To buy pig food

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma C. is a widow  who lives in Magsasaka, Brgy. Teresa, Narra, Palawan. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a general store, a farm, and a fishing business. She has one child who is 25 years old. 

Vilma joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past nine loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Vilma has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 25,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of 63,000 PHP, bettering the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 10th cycle loan, she is borrowing 25,000, which she intends to use to buy more stocks for her general store and gear and parts for her fishing boat. She hopes that she could save enough from her earnings for the future education of her grandson and improve the quality of life of her family.  Vilma C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: inventory for general store; fishing gear; fishing boat parts

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace G. is currently in the business of selling bread, simsim (sesame seeds) and groundnuts (peanuts), and is requesting a loan to stock tomatoes and onions to sell. Grace is 41 years old and is married with a husband that is a peasant. She has 5 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: Stock tomatoes and onions to sell

loans.name: Bayarbat

texts.en:
Mr Bayarbat is 47 years old and lives with his wife, mother and 2 sons, Bilguun (20) and Ariunjargal (22), in his mother's apartment in Ulaanbaatar City. The two sons are both students in the university. Since 2002, Mr. Bayarbat has been running a taxi business consistently. He is a very hard-working man. His goal is to give a proper high education for his kids. 

His wife, Narantsetseg, rents a stall in Bumbugur, the second largest indoor market, and has been doing it since 2008. She sells clothes. Once a month she travels by train to Ereen. That is a city on the Chinese border. There she buys goods on the local market. Then she sells them for a profit.  Now the two sons' school term is coming. The reason Mr Bayarbat is requesting this loan is he wants to increase his wife's business current assets and inventory and by that, pay for two sons' annual student fees.

loans.use: To increase his wife's business assets and thereby pay his sons' school fees for the year

loans.name: Tiessiri 1 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Tièssiri 1 est constitué de 10 femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles polygames à Madoudiarrabougou, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités hivernales. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres le petit mil, le sésame, le pois de terre, l’arachide et le haricot. 
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt,  DJELIKA D., la présidente du groupe, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de main d’œuvre  pour entretenir environs 1,8 hectare de petit mil et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Dioïla et Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice 70.000FCFA en fin de campagne.
texts.en:
The Tièssiri 1 group is made up of ten married women who average 40 years of age and have four children each. They live in polygamous families in Madoudiarrabougou, one of the villages in the prefecture of Dioïla, in the region of Koulikoro, Mali's second administrative region. They are collaborating with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the goal of better organising their winter activities. They grow among other things pearl millett, sesame, peas, peanuts and beans. They are on their third farming loan and the previous loans have been repaid in full. With this new loan, Djelika Dembelle, the president of the group, is planning on buying intrants and small materials as well as paying the labor costs of maintaining around 1.8 hectares of pearl millet and peanuts. The produce is sold in the towns of Dioïla and Massiqui after the harvests to a customer base made up of men and women. They are counting on making a profit of 70.000FCFA at the end of the season.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Labor, sowing, fertilizers, weedkillers, hoeing and small equipment

loans.name: Vuoch's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four members who live in Preak Ta Hang village in Kandal province. The members have selected Mrs. Vuoch C., 38, as their group leader. Each group member will use their portion of the loan to support their individual businesses.

Mrs. Vuoch C. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate vegetable and rice. Her husband, Mr. La vong, is a construction worker in the village. Both occupations combined, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. To increase their family income, Mrs. Vuoch C. will use the loan to buy a fishing boat for fishing. The couple has seven children: two are seamstresses in the garment factory, one is a clothes seller, three are students in the local school, while the youngest is only two years old.

loans.use: To buy a fishing boat for fishing

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia A. is currently in the business of selling local brew at home and is requesting a loan to stock crates of beer to sell. Cecilia is 37 years old and is married with a husband that is a builder. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar.

loans.use: Stock crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Tiessiri 2 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  membres du groupe Tièssiri  2 sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans et  en moyenne  3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Madoudiarrabougou, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités hivernales. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont le petit mil, l’arachide et le haricot. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne et tous les deux prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt,  KAFOUNE S. compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour et de sarclage pour entretenir environ 1 hectare petit mil et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Dioïla et Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 35.000FCFA environ en fin de   campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Tièssiri 2 group are married women on average 38 years old with three children. Most live in polygamous families in Madoudiarrabougou, one of the villages belonging to the Dioïla Prefecture in the Koulikoro region, part of the 2nd administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to better organise their winter activities. Their cash crops are millet, peanuts and beans. This is their third farming loan and the two preceding ones have been duly repaid. With this new loan Kafoune S. intends to buy seeds and fertilizer, small farming equipment and pay labor costs in relation to ploughing and weeding, to cultivate approximately 1 hectare (2.5 acres) of millet and peanuts. After harvesting the crops are sold in Dioïla and Massigui to both men and women customers. She hopes to reach earnings of about 35,000 FCFA by the end of the farming season.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Labor costs (weeding), seeds, fertilizer and small farming equipment

loans.name: Nort

texts.en: Nort S., 34, is married and lives with three of her children in the Kampong Cham province. She and her husband are farmers who typically make about $1 (US) each day. Besides this business, her husband also operates a recycling business in the village. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Nort S. included. She would like to take out a loan of $400 to reinvest in recycling business. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: Reinvest in recycling business.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en: Lucia R. is currently in the business of selling dried fish, tomatoes and onions at the market and is requesting a loan to stock jerrycans of cooking oil to sell. Lucia is 38 years old and is married with a husband that is a peasant. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

loans.use: Stock jerrycans of cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Nusrat's Group

texts.en:
Nusrat lives in a historic city called Lahore. Lahore is the second largest city of Pakistan and known for its history and culture. She has been living in a three-room brick house with her family in an area named Saddar Cantt for the last 20 years. She is the mother of three children, two sons and a daughter. All of them are getting their education. Her eldest son is in 9th standard (grade) and the younger one is in 8th standard, while her daughter is studying in 7th standard. Nusrat knows the importance of education very well and wants to give the best possible education to her children. 

Her husband does a job in government sector. After his day job, he operates his shop in the market from where he sells spare parts of cars and motorbikes. Nusrat herself performs her duty of a seamstress. She sews clothes for her neighborhood clients. She is well-known person in her area for her sewing, which helps her to get regular orders. 

Nusrat has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s spare parts business. With the loan amount, he will buy spare parts of different vehicles and increase his sales by selling them to his customers. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and is in her 2nd loan cycle.

loans.use: Purchase spare parts of vehicles for her husband's business

loans.name: Kakoma Twebeiseho, Bushenyi Group

texts.en:
Hard-working K. Mary has been running a retail shop from Kakoma trading centre in Bushenyi district, where she sells general merchandise. This has been operating for over 10 years on this road. The married mother of 6 children confirms that she has had problems in restocking her business as the stock available does not satisfy the customers' demands.

Therefore Mary is seeking a loan to help her buy more goods with the hope to earn more income and be in a position to cater for her family needs, thus improve her standard of living.

loans.use: business restocking

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Sem S., 54, is a widowed farmer who lives with two children. Living in the Kampong Cham province, she typically makes $1 (US) every day and is aided by her children who work as blacksmiths. The Kampong Cham area has not seen favorable weather conditions for farming this past year. Along with increased inflation, it has been a difficult year economically in much of Cambodia. Sem S. is asking for a loan of $500 to purchase blacksmith tools for his children.

loans.use: To purchase blacksmith tools.

loans.name: Mr. Mus Nhoem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of 14 members who live in Tuol Pongro village in Takeo province. The members have selected Mr. Mus N. as their village bank president. Each member will use their portion of the loan to support their individual businesses. 

Mr. Mus N., 47, and his wife, Mrs. Khon Khem, are farmers who own a one-point-four hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to support their family. Mus also works as a rock breaker to support his family. His field has infertile soil and is infected with insects. To improve the production of rice, Mr. Mus N. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizers, pesticides, and use the rest of the loan to hire a plow machine to plow his field. He is a father of four children, all of whom are studying in school and are helping their parents’ businesses.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide

loans.name: Sou

texts.en: Sou S., 27, is married and lives with two of her children in the Kampong Cham province. She is a farmer, while her husband works in construction. They both make $3 (US) of profit a day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Sou S. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of $900 to purchase fertilizer. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence S. is currently in the business of selling water pipes, taps, electrical materials, etc., in her shop, and she is requesting a loan to stock more water taps and electrical materials to sell. Florence is 31 years old and is married with a husband that is an electrician. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase and stock generators and solar equipment and put them for sale.

loans.use: Stock more water taps and electrical materials to sell

loans.name: Kheiv

texts.en: Kheiv P., 43, is a professional tailor, making US$ 3 daily in Kampong Cham province. She is married and has four children living at home. Her husband, Kheng Khan, makes approximately US$ 2.50 daily, raising pigs and growing rice. Kheiv P. would like a loan of US$ 800 to purchase fertilizer and more farmland.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and more farmland.

loans.name: Azra's Group

texts.en:
Azra lives in a big city called Lahore in Pakistan.  Lahore is a city well known for its history and culture. 

Azra is 48 years-old. She has three rooms in a brick house in the area named Saddr Cantt and she has been living there with her family for the last 30 years.  She has given birth to seven children. Her four youngest children managed to get an education but, due to poor finances, Azra couldn’t educate her elder children. Her eldest daughter works in a cotton factory. Her elder son is a goldsmith while the younger one works in the government sector as a government employee and also operates a furniture making business after coming back from his day job. He has a shop in the market where he makes furniture on order. He has hired two workers in his shop and pays them on a monthly basis. They also take care of the shop in his absence. 

Azra’s husband also works in the government sector and is near his retirement.  

Azra has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her son's furniture making business. With the loan amount he will buy wood, nails and wood polisher in bulk which will enable him to make more furniture to complete the orders of his customers on time. 
Azra is confident that by investing money in her son’s business, he will be able to improve his business situation and increase his income. 

Azra is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her fourth loan cycle.

loans.use: To purchase required items for a furniture making business.

loans.name: Nhanh

texts.en: Nhanh K., 19, is married and lives with her husband in Battambong Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality rice products. She sells vegetables and fruit for an income of USD daily.
