Her husband farms with his mother, earning an income of USD 2 daily.  K. is requesting a loan of USD 300 to purchase corn to sell.  In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more corn to sell.

loans.name: Susa

texts.en: At present, Susa S. is in the business of selling crates of beer at a bar.  She is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer and popular wines such as white wine, etc. to sell.  Susa is 36 years-old and is married with a husband who is a police officer. She has three children and they all go to school.  With the extra profits generated through her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her restaurant.

loans.use: To stock beer.

loans.name: Mrs. Sophea Prum Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of 12 people who live in Tuol Pongro village in Takeo province. They have selected Mrs. Sophea P. as the village bank president. The group members will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Sophea P. is a congee and Khmer cake seller in the local village, and she earns decent income to support her famiL.. She is also a pig breeder while her husband, Mr. Ork Sam, is a farmer who owns a two-point-eight hectare plot of land and cultivates rice to support his famiL.. Her husband’s rice field has infertile soil. So to improve production, Mrs. Sophea P. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizers. She is a mother of two children, both of whom attend school and help their parents’ businesses.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers

loans.name: Neang

texts.en: Neang S. is highly skilled at cultivating crops on her own farmland and began this work when she was unmarried.   She is now married with two school-aged children. Her husband helps be responsible for the family by working in construction. Growing crops is an annual activity with which she has had great success. She is able to plant the crops at least twice a year following both the rainy and dry seasons. The coming rainfall is good for growing, however, Neang S. has insufficient capital to use on her farm. Therefore, Neang S. is seeking a loan to use towards purchasing fertilizers, insecticides, a pump machine and seeds for planting.

loans.use: To use towards purchasing fertilizers, insecticides, a pump machine, and seeds.

loans.name: Phoeun's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Phoeun N., 40, is the village bank president selected by the six members of this group loan, who are located in Krang Cheu Neang village in Kandal province. All members will use their portion of the loan for different purposes.
Mrs. Phoeun N. and her husband, Mr. Sok On, are farmers who own a 1.20 hectare of land to cultivate rice for a living. Mrs. Phoeun N. will use the loan to buy fertilizers, pesticides and to pay for farming laborers to cultivate rice.  Aside from being a farmer, Mrs. Phoeun N. is also chicken seller in the local market. Both these occupations combined, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. The couple has three children, all of whom are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, pesticides and to pay for farming laborers to cultivate rice

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice M., age 38, is the sole proprietor of her baker’s goods business in Kongowea, Mombasa. She has been in the baking business in Kongowea for 10 years. This will be her first loan from KADET. With her loan, Beatrice plans to purchase baking flour and bags that she can use for transporting her baked products. 

She and her husband, Mathew Shabira, have seven children. Her husband assists her in financially supporting the family. Beatrice plans to use the anticipated profit from this loan to help pay for the education of her children. She hopes one day to open a whole bakery store.

loans.use: To buy flour and bags for transporting her baked goods

loans.name: Hem

texts.en: Hem H., 42, is married and resides with his wife in the province of Batambong, Cambodia, an area known for quality rice products. He is a construction worker for an income of $5 USD per day. His wife sells desserts, earning an income of $4 USD per day. H. is requesting a loan of $1,000 USD to purchase a motorbike for the family to use. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to repair his house. This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. H.'s wife appears in the photograph because H. is not available.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the family to use

loans.name: Monika

texts.en: Monika D. is currently in the business of selling tea and local Sudanese bread (tamia and legemat) in an iron-sheet-built restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock foodstuff such as beans, rice, and maize to cook and sell. Monika is 51 years old and is widowed. She has seven children, three of whom go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her restaurant by building a permanent large room that can accommodate many chairs and tables for customer service.

loans.use: To stock foodstuff such as beans, rice, and maize to cook and sell

loans.name: Kiano Ole

texts.en:
Kiano has been rearing and selling animals in Naivasha town for four years. He is 47 years old and married to Eunice Kutenoi, and they have three children.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend, and this will be his first loan. He plans to buy 15 goats to rear and sell later at a profit. Kiano hopes to venture into real estate in the future by building rental houses in Naivasha town.

loans.use: To buy 15 goats to rear and sell later at a profit

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Srey S., age 37, sells cakes, beverages, and vegetables. She earns an income of USD 3 per day. Her husband is a taxi driver, earning an income of USD 5 per day. They live with their five children in Battambong Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality rice products.

S. is requesting a loan in the amount of USD 800 to purchase a motorbike for her children to use to commute to school. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to pay for repairs to her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle for family use, particularly for commuting to school

loans.name: Edina

texts.en:
Edina S., age 35, is a vendor of beans, rice, and maize flour at her local market. She is requesting a loan in order to stock bags of pulses and baking flour to sell. Edina's husband is a teacher. They have three children, all of whom are enrolled in school. 

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a shop to allow for more effective stocking of goods.

loans.use: To stock bags of pulses and baking flour for sale

loans.name: Mira

texts.en:
Mira A. is a young woman from Jineen city.  Mira is married and has two sons and one daughter. Her husband works in Israel as a construction worker.  Since her husband's work is not stable, Mira and her husband decided to purchase cows and start working in dairy production.

Mira and her husband produce all kinds of dairy products such as yogurt, cheese and milk at her house. Mira sells those products to her neighbors. Since she started building a reputation Mira and her husband decided to purchase a third cow and expand her business. With the help of FATEN's loan and savings she could buy one.

Mira appears in the picture above at FATEN's office.

loans.use: To purchase a third cow

loans.name: Genty

texts.en: Genty K. is currently in the business of selling bread, groundnut paste, and cooking oil  and is requesting a loan to stock fresh fish to fry and sell.  Genty is 32 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

loans.use: Stock fresh fish to fry and sell

loans.name: Nyarubira Twimukye Group, Bushenyi

texts.en:
B. Joy is a hard-working business lady. The 53-year-old married mother of 9 children. some of them (3) still attending school sweats her guts out selling agro-produce such as maize, millet, beans, and groundnuts in a small rural area of Kashenshero, Bushenyi. She has been doing this business for the last 21 years. She started with little capital but with inspiration from her mother-in-law and gets many customers who buy her products for food consumption such as hotel owners. 

She is able to make 100,000 Ugandan shillings monthly. This is a fair earning by Ugandan standards, and as such she requires a loan that will help her buy more food supplies for the business. Then she will be able to meet the customers' demand and also get more revenue. 

She belongs to a group of members and they insure each other in paying back the loan.

loans.use: more stock into the business

loans.name: Lona

texts.en: Lona K. is currently in the business of selling exercise books, pens, sharpeners, pencils, etc in a book shop and is requesting a loan to stock boxes of chalks, file holders and textbooks to sell.  Lona is 53 years old and is widowed.   She has 6 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar.

loans.use: Stock boxes of chalks, file holders and textbooks to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Norn Long Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan has 12 people who live in Trach village in Takeo province. Mrs. Norn L. is the village bank president selected by the other group members, who will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Norn L., 58, and her husband, Mr. Horl Ny, are farmers who own a two-hectare plot of land where they grow crop to support their famiL.. Her field has infertile soil, so to improve crop production, Mrs. Norn L. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizers. She is a mother of four children: one is a teacher, two are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the other is attending school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers

loans.name: Ludia

texts.en: Ludia C. is currently in the business of selling bags of sugar, rice, and beans in her store and is requesting a loan to stock bags of maize flour and baking flour to sell.  Ludia is 40 years old and is married to a husband who is a retired teacher. She has 6 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: Stock bags of maize flour and baking flour to sell

loans.name: Khut

texts.en: Khut N., 38, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Battambong Province, Cambodia, an area known for high quality rice products. She sells Chinese noodle for an income of USD 5 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 3 per day.  N. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a new motorbike for her husband so he can operate his business efficiently. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. N.'s husband appears in the photograph because N. was not available.

loans.use: buy a new motorbike for her husband

loans.name: Butiti Tweimukye, Kyenjojo Group

texts.en:
I. Clovis is a 42-year-old married father of 8 boisterous schoolchildren. To shoulder his responsibility for providing for them, he has over the course of the last 10 years been operating a home products retail shop in Butiti Trading centre, Mubende District, alongside a butcher shop. His business has not been without setbacks since its beginning; he has had to bear with myriad challenges, such as the lack of steady income inflow. However, his business has remained active. This  he attributes principally to the good understanding he has struck with his clientele. 

Before his current businesses, Clovis was a hawker in Kampala, moving with his goods from place to place. In a month, Clovis says he makes more than 320,000 Ugandan shillings, a figure he admits will not substantively make his business grow in the near future. He is therefore seeking a loan to lend countenance to his business so that he is able to do restocking for his shop.

loans.use: buying more stock for resale

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary M. is currently in the business of selling mixed goods such as: beer, soda, sugar and beans in a retail shop and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer and sodas to sell.  Mary is 35 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar where beer will be sold and open up a shop for other goods like sugar and beans.

loans.use: Stock more crates of beer and soda to sell

loans.name: Maurice

texts.en:
Maurice O. is 47 years old and is married to Rosemary Auma and they have four children who are all school-going and are under 18 years of age. They live in a rural area called Ngiya. 

Maurice is a farmer and normally sells his farm produce to earn a living. He is applying for a loan from Kadet Ltd to buy “My Sunshine Box” which will help him in lighting his home. Jacob’s children use lanterns for lighting and this is too cumbersome for them. They struggle a lot when doing their homework at night. Jacob has serviced a loan before with Kadet Ltd and he paid it well without any difficulties.

He hopes and waits for the day when electricity will be installed in his rural home.

loans.use: To buy "My Sunshine Box"

loans.name: Seav

texts.en:
Mrs. Seav S. owns a shop where she sells coffee to people who are her nearby villagers. By doing this, she is able to make 12 thousands riel (about US$ 3) per day. Seav S. has another financial earner in her husband who is a merchant. He always buys rice or other merchandise in bulk to store for a while before selling at a profit. The family lives together with a young child who is enrolled in school. 

Seav S. sees that the business of her husband is very profitable and she hopes to enlarge it by requesting a loan for her husband use as capital to increase the larger quantity of his inventory to resell.

loans.use: To have a larger quantity of inventory to resell

loans.name: Furkat

texts.en:
Cattle farming is an economic activity dedicated to the raising of animals in order to generate revenue from the animals and the products they provide. Furkat has earned a living from raising cattle since he was young. He's married and has 4 children who, according to Furkat’s words, are his reason for living. It should be said that the low incomes available to people in this rural area aren't enough to maintain a family and, for this reason, Furkat works enormously hard to provide a better standard of living for his wife and children. 

Furkat urgently needs to buy animals such as cows and calves. He's applied for a loan of 4000 Somoni.     


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing calves to raise

loans.name: Jacob

texts.en:
Jacob J., age 51, is a farmer. He sells his farm produce in order to earn a living. He is applying for a loan from Kadet Ltd. in order to buy a "My Sunshine Box," an electrical product that will help him to light his home more efficiently. At present, Jacob’s family uses lantern lamps for lighting, and this is highly cumbersome for them. The children struggle considerably when doing their homework at night. He is eager for the day when electricity will be installed in his rural home. 

Jacob has serviced a loan before with Kadet Ltd., and he paid it off promptly and without any difficulties.

Jacob is married to Margaret Odongo and they have four children, all of whom are under 18 years of age and all of whom attend school. The family lives in a rural area called Ngiya.

loans.use: To buy a "My Sunshine Box" for home lighting purposes

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy Opina, age 35, is a vendor of fish, simsim, and groundnuts at her local market. She and is requesting a loan in order to stock more dried fish and bags of groundnuts to sell.  Lucy's husband is a businessman and they have four children, all of whom attend school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a house to offer for rent.

loans.use: To stock more dried fish and bags of groundnuts to sell

loans.name: James

texts.en:
B. James is a farmer and livestock breeder in Kanyansheko, Ibanda. He grows bananas and coffee and raises livestock. Thanks to his good management and customer care skills, these businesses generate him a monthly profit of 280,000 Ugandan shillings. James tells us that he was encouraged by his parents to save money, which is how he was able to buy his own land. Now that he owns his own farmland, he is able to quit his previous business of selling waragi, a local brew.

Through hard work, James looks forward to improving his banana plantation through mulching and other farm inputs, the lack of which is reducing his returns currently. This will give his ventures improved returns for some time to come. This loan will be used for the purchase of pesticides and mulches as well as other materials that will allow him to achieve better yields. His motive is to earn more money so that he can pay his children’s school fees and to expand his businesses for more income.

James is the father of three children with only one attending school at the moment.

loans.use: To buy pesticides and mulches as well as other materials that will allow his farm to achieve better yields

loans.name: Shirali

texts.en:
K. Shirali is a hardworking man who works in the cattle raising business. He is married with four children. He works hard to provide everything his family needs. Presently, Shirali is sacrificing and working hard to make his business grow.

He is requesting a loan that will allow him to purchase baby cows. He plans to feed and raise the cows. His goal is to then get the most return from the sale of the cows' milk products. This will be his first loan with IMON and Kiva. His evaluation shows he is qualified to receive the loan.

These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase young cattle

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick O. is 42 years old and is married to Jane Adhiambo. They have six children who are all school going children and are under 18 years. They live in a rural area called Ngiya.

Patrick owns a retail shop. He is applying for a loan from Kadet Ltd to buy “My Sunshine Box,” which will help him to light his home. Patrick’s home is in the interior of Ngiya Town and the supply of electricity to that area is limited. He was introduced to Kadet Ltd by a friend who is a client with us. The Sunshine Box will help the children study well at night.

He hopes and waits for the day when electricity will be installed in his rural home.

loans.use: To buy a "Sunshine Box"

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary T. is 35 years old. She is married; her husband is a peasant. She has four children. Her children go to school.

Mary is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs at her restaurant. She is requesting a loan so she can stock more foodstuffs in the restaurant.

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to provide food and other essential needs for her family.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs for her restaurant

loans.name: Mrs. Sok Leang Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. S. L., 59, is the village bank president selected by 18 people who live in Trach village in Takeo province. Each member of the village bank will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. Mrs. S. L. and her husband, Mr. Sy S., are farmers who own more than one-hectare plot of land to grow rice and potatoes to support their family. She is also a pig breeder. Her field has infertile soil, so to improve production, Mrs. S. L. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizers and use the rest of the loan to buys more piglets for breeding. She has one child who is a construction worker.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers

loans.name: Abdumumin

texts.en:
N. Abdumumin is 52 years old. He is married with four children of school age.

Abdumumin is a manufacturer. He produces wooden doors and window frames. His shop is located in his house. By working in the business for eight years, Abdumumin has become a rather experienced master. He now has students to whom he teaches the business.

Because he produces high quality goods at acceptable prices, Abdumumin has many customers. He sells the doors and window frames from his house. There is also a trading place located in the local market.

In general the business is very successful and generates a stable income for his family.

Now, Abdumumin is planning to employ an additional woodworker so he can expand his business. For this reason, he requests 4,500 Somoni.

loans.use: To employ another worker

loans.name: Wilfred

texts.en:
Wilfred O. is 35 years old and is married to Judith Auma. They have eight children who are all school going children and are under 18 years of age. They live in a rural area called Ngiya.

Wilfred spends some of his time farming.

In the rural area where he lives, they have no electricity. He is applying for a loan to buy “My Sunshine Box,” which will help him to light his home. His children have been using kerosene lamps to read with and they have been straining a lot. He has serviced previous loans and paid them back without any difficulties.

He hopes and waits for the day when electricity will be installed in his rural home.

loans.use: To buy "My Sunshine Box"

loans.name: Benkadi 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  membres du groupe Benkadi 1 sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 53 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles polygames à Bablena, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités hivernales. 
Les spéculations cultivées par les membres de ce groupe sont le petit mil, l’arachide et le haricot. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, AMINATA D., la présidente du groupe, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de main d’œuvre  pour entretenir environ 1,5 hectare de petit mil et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée de revendeurs. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 50.000FCFA  en fin de campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Benkadi 1 group are married women on average 53 years old with four children. They live in polygamous families in Bablena, one of the villages belonging to the Dioïla Prefecture in the Koulikoro region, part of the 2nd administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to better organise their winter activities. Their cash crops are millet, peanuts and beans. This is their third farming loan and the two preceding ones have been duly repaid. With this new loan Aminata D. (the group’s president) intends to buy seeds and fertilizer, small farming equipment and pay labor costs to cultivate approximately 1.5 hectares (3.7 acres) of millet and peanuts. After harvesting the crops are sold in Massigui to mainly retail merchants. She hopes to reach earnings of about 50,000 FCFA by the end of the farming season.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Labor costs, seeds and fertilizer and small farming equipment

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth B. is married and has four children. She has been through junior high school. Elizabeth sells smoked fish at Takoradi. Her husband is a chain saw operator.  Elizabeth uses her income to help her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Elizabeth will use the loan to purchase more fresh fish to smoke for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Elizabeth plans to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: purchase more fresh fish to smoke for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy more ingredients to prepare doughnuts to sell

loans.name: Olimjon

texts.en:
R. Olimjon, age 28, owns a computer club where people can use computers, play video games, and work. He rents a small office on the ground floor of a housing complex. He has been in this business for the past three years. When Olimjon receives credit, he plans to restore several computer systems that are currently out of order. He will also buy additional computers. This will provide Olimjon with an opportunity to increase the number of working computers in his club. This credit will help people who do not have home access to a computer to visit Olimjon's club and use computers there. Some of his customers will pursue improving their computer skills and others can make new friends through video games and gain necessary educational information. The loan will greatly improve Olimjon’s income and his family's living standards.

loans.use: To buy new computers for his computer center and to restore existing ones

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more cloth for sale

loans.name: Tiessiri 3 Group

texts.fr:
Tièssiri 3 est constitué de  huit femmes mariées qui ont en moyenne  49 ans, 4 enfants et qui vivent majoritairement dans des familles polygames à Madoudiarrabougou, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités hivernales. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont le petit mil, l’arachide, le sésame, le pois de terre et le haricot. 
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne et tous les  deux prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt,  AFOU D. compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de main d’œuvre  pour entretenir environ 1, 3 hectare d’arachide.
La production est vendue au niveau de la ville de Dioïla après les récoltes à une clientèle composée essentiellement de revendeurs. 
Les femmes du groupe Tièssiri 3 comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 45.000FCFA en fin de  campagne.
texts.en:
Tiessiri 3 is made up of eight married women. On average they are 49 years old and have four children. The majority of them live in polygamous families in Madoudiarrabougou, a village in the prefecture of Dioila, in the region of Koulikoro, the second administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the microfinance organization, Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of better organizing their winter agricultural activities. The crops cultivated are peanuts, sesame, earth peas, and green beans. They are on their third farming loan and both of their other previous loans were properly repaid. With this new loan, Afou D. will buy seeds and small tools, and pay the laborer costs of maintaining approximately 1.3 hectares of peanuts. She sells her products after the harvest at the city level in Diolila to a client base essentially composed of commodity dealers. The women of the Tiessiri 3 group expect an average profit of 45.000 FCFA after paying back the farming loan.

Translated from French by Katherine Evans, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay for seeds, labor and tools

loans.use: to purchase more of her  goods to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy more of her goods for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase more slippers for sale

loans.name: Maame Adwoa

texts.en: Maame Adwoa M. sells cloth at Takoradi. Maame Adwoa has received junior high education. She is married to a farmer and has ten dependents. She is responsible and helps her husband to provide the basic needs of her family. Her loan will be used to buy more cloth for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: buy more cloth for sale

loans.use: buy more foodstuffs for sale

loans.use: buy more frozen meat and fish to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 45-year-old married man and father of five children, two of whom are employed. A resident of Lebanon, he has over 25 years of experience working with spare car parts and car repair. He is the main provider of his family, although his two working children try to help him with a small amount of support. He is requesting $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to increase his inventory and therefore increase his sales. In the future, he plans to open a bigger store to trade and sell spare parts. He told us that he would like to one day open a big center.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his picture, not indicating his name and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support of Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen: Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese microfinance sector since 1999. Originally a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specializing in microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l., we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To increase his inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more salted fish to sell

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah M., 61, and her husband Wilfredo, also 61, are working hard to cover their daily expenses. For the past 12 years Sarah has been running her own restaurant. Recently the price of gas for her stove has gone up, creating some difficulties, but Sarah has been able to manage her way through.

Sarah is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan to help her purchase additional ingredients for her restaurant, including chicken, pork, and beef. The additional ingredients will allow her to keep cooking and generating income. She hopes that they will also allow her to attract more customers and eventually expand the business.

Sarah has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) since 2004 and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.* She dreams of living a stable life and saving enough money to cover emergencies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. Composed of 15 to 30 community partners, the fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Ingredients for food vending

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
In his mid 50’s, Patrick M. has been running an agricultural enterprise for over 14 years and is still at his best, proving to fellow agriculturalists in the area that he can make it. Having been motivated by personal traits and inspired by his parents for quite some time, hardworking Patrick had a vision to develop a banana plantation alongside his coffee-sales enterprise and livestock farming. He has been practicing this from Kanyansheko, Ibanda where he earns 320,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis.

However, Patrick's main drawback is harvesting poor quantities, so with this loan he will be able to purchase agricultural inputs such as manure. This will make it possible for him to achieve greater output and earn more revenue to support his family of six children and a wife at home and to further his goal of expanding his business and educating his children, who are still attending school.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs such as manure for the banana plantaion

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy additional goods to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Ma. Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina R., 38, and her husband Freddie, 36, have three children and work hard to cover daily expenses and their children's education. One of their children is in elementary school and another in high school, while the third is too young to yet attend school. Freddie works abroad, and Cristina owns a toy store which she has been running for the past five years.

Cristina has requested a loan of PHP 8,000 to help her restock the inventory of her store. She plans to purchase more toys, hoping that the expanded inventory will allow her to earn more money and grow the business. Cristina has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) since 2005 and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.*

Cristina hopes that one day her business will allow her to save enough to own a house.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. Composed of 15 to 30 community partners, the fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase an inventory of toys

loans.name: Maame

texts.en:
Maame Y. sells kenkey at takoradi. She has received senior high education. She is married and has two children. Her husband is into carpentry. She is responsible by supporting her husband in giving the children a better education.

Maame’s loan will be used to buy more maize to use for her kenkey production. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to buy a plot of land.

To prepare her kenkey, Maame buys maize from the market and soaks it in enough water to soften it. She washes it on the third day and sends it to the mill to be milled. She then makes a mixture of dough from the milled wet corn and leaves it to prove (ferment and rise).

On the next day she divides the proved dough into two, uses one part for her firm half-cooked dough (she mixes it with water to get it in a porridge form and cooks it for some time to get a firm mixture or texture) and then pounds it in a mortar for some time. The pounding makes it taste different from the normal kenkey. Finally, it is wrapped in a corn husk and boiled. Then it is ready to be served with any kind of sauce.

loans.use: To buy more maize to use for her kenkey production

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 28-year-old married man and father of two young children who attend school. He has been working as a furniture carpenter for the past 25 years and has run his own shop since 1998. He specializes in making wooden furniture designs. He works independently in his business, but collaborates with some galleries in his town and on customer request. Today, he is requesting a loan of $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to buy more wood in order to increase his business productivity.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his picture, not indicating his name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen s.a.l

Originally a microcredit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specializing in microfinance.
At Ameen s.a.l., we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.
Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for its micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To buy more wood

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita D., aged 43, and her husband Alex, aged 44, have four children – two are in college, one is in high school and one is in elementary school. Anita and Alex work hard to cover daily expenses and the cost of their children's education. For the past 15 years, Anita has owned and run her own sari-sari (general) store to generate income to help with the family's expenses.
Anita is requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP to purchase extra inventory for her store, including school supplies, groceries and soft drinks. She hopes the added inventory will attract more customers and that her expanded business will generate more revenue.
Anita has been a member of Kiva partner, the Center for Community Transformation (CCT), since 2009, and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings*. She hopes that the income from her business will allow her to continue paying for her children's education.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase school supplies, groceries and soft drinks

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty D. is 29 years old and married to a teacher. She has two children, who go to school. Betty is currently in the business of selling tomatoes, onions and cooking oil. She is requesting a loan to stock dried fish to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a shop.

loans.use: To stock dried fish to sell

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa C., aged 36, and her husband have six children – four of them are at school, one is working, and one is currently living at home. Elsa works hard to cover her daily expenses by direct selling fiber drinks, coffee and chocolate drinks to generate a small profit each month.
Elsa has applied for a loan of 12,000 PHP to help restock her supplies. She hopes that the purchase of additional health drinks will allow her to expand her business and generate more revenue. Elsa has been a member of Kiva partner, the Center for Community Transformation (CCT), for several loan cycles and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings*. Elsa hopes that her profits will allow her to continue to run her business and that all of her children will successfully finish school.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase health drinks

loans.name: Gogonyo Women And Orphan Association-Kampala Group

texts.en:
S. Sarah, 48, has relied on her suave, self-motivated and strong-hearted entrepreneurial spirit to make progress in her small kiosk business in Nsambya-Kampala. Sarah, who is married and has eight children, was pep-talked into this business by one of her closest friends. This was her first business and has, for all this time, been her main source of livelihood. It is a modest business but Sarah has been able to live on its proceeds.
Mainly, Sarah sells edibles such as roast bananas, chicken and local prepared dishes. With the help of this loan, she intends to boost her business in the way she knows best – by buying more foods such as maize flour, rice, cassava and beans. Her optimism is sky high that she will be able to make more money when she buys a greater variety of food to prepare for her old, new and prospective customers.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs for her business

loans.name: Paska

texts.en: Paska L. is 40 years old and married to a peasant. She has four children who all go to school. Paska is currently in the business of selling dried fish and tomatoes at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock jerrycans of cooking oil and Irish potatoes to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to set up a charcoal store to sell bags of charcoal.

loans.use: To stock jerrycans of cooking oil and Irish potatoes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 25-year-old married man with one child. He lives in Lebanon. He has owned a tractor for the past five years. His work involves excavating land for cultivation or construction. He works upon the request of clients who ask for his service. He is thankful for his business because he has been able to build a good business reputation. Today, he is requesting a loan of $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to perform much-needed maintenance work on his tractor’s engine and body.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his picture, not indicating his name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen s.a.l.
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese microfinance sector since 1999. Originally a microcredit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specializing in microfinance.
At Ameen s.a.l., we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.
Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for its microloan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To perform maintenance work on his tractor’s engine and body

loans.name: Abendowooza Women Development Association-Kampala Group

texts.en: M. Irene, aged 36, has been running her clothes and poultry sales businesses for the last eight years in Lubowa-Kampala. Irene began as a teacher and a politician, and she had always heard the oft-used classroom adage – 'hard work pays'. Irene wanted to use this as a precept in her business and used it she has. Her clothes business brings in 100,000 UGX weekly and she is upbeat about her future business prospects in the wake of getting this loan, which will give her a solid start-up. This married mother of five wants to buy more clothes for resale. She believes that with more clothes sales she will be able to earn more money.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for resale

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose T. makes a living selling clothes such as dresses, pants and head dresses. She is applying for a loan to buy more items to sell to her customers. Rose is 45 years old and her husband makes a living working for an NGO. They have five children, all of whom attend school. With the extra profits made possible by this loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family to live in.

loans.use: to buy additional products to sell to her customers

loans.name: Benroeo

texts.en: Benroeo J. makes a living selling cooking oil, beans and dried fish at a local market, and is applying for a loan to buy tomatoes and onions to sell to her customers. She is 34 years old and married to a farmer. They have three children, all of whom attend school. With the extra profits made possible by this loan, Benroeo hopes to be able to build her own shop.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes and onions to sell to her customers

loans.name: Nerry

texts.en:
Nerry F. is 51 years old, married and has three children. She and her husband work hard to meet their expenses and  run three businesses: a tailor shop, a clothing store and an internet cafe. Nerry is very busy obtaining clothing to sell, and making sure that her computers are in working order.

Nerry has applied for a loan of PHP 20,000 to repair some of her computers, buy ink for her printers and restock her clothing store. She hopes that the loan will help her continue to run a stable business.  

Nerry is a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT), where she has received and repaid several loans, and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.* She hopes that she will continue to be able to pay for her children's education while covering her costs.

* All CCT community partners and clients are members of fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is made up of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to buy new items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary D. makes a living selling rice, cooking oil and vegetables at a local market. She is applying for a loan to buy corn flour and bags of beans to sell.  She is 47 years old and married to a soldier. They have five children who are not currently enrolled in school. With the extra profits made possible by this loan, she hopes to be able to afford to send her children to school.

loans.use: To buy corn flour and bags of beans to sell

loans.name: Youmina

texts.en: Youmina A. makes a living selling sorghum, millet and other items and has applied for a loan to buy more millet to sell to her customers. She is 49 years old and married to a policeman. She has five children, all of whom go to school.  With the extra profits made possible by this loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar to sell beverages that are popular locally.

loans.use: to buy more millet to sell to her customers

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 26-year-old married man with two young children. He has five years of experience working with mobile phones. He began as an employee in a mobile shop and opened his own store in 2007. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to increase his merchandise selection and purchase prepaid telephone cards to sell. The majority of mobile phone users in Lebanon purchase these prepaid cards. In the future, he is looking to further expand his business and increase his capital. 

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him (for example, blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his picture and not indicating his name and location). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese microfinance sector since 1999. Originally a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l., we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To increase his merchandise selection and purchase prepaid telephone cards

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Charity M. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and firewood. She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Charity is 46 years old and is widowed.   She has six children and her children go to school.  

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a charcoal store to increase her profits.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. is currently in the business of selling simsim and groundnut and is requesting a loan to stock bags of maize, millet, and sorghum to sell.  Mary is 43 years old and is married. Her husband is a peasant. They have five children, all of whom attend school.  

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize, millet, and sorghum

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Charity M. presently sells green vegetables and some fruits (tomatoes, oranges, gavva, and so forth).  She is requesting a loan to stock dried fish to sell. Charity is 34 years old and is married. Her husband is a security guard. They have one child, who does not go to school.  

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open another business where she can sell clothes and shoes.

loans.use: Stock dried fish to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 48-year-old married man and father of three children from Lebanon. He is the main income provider for his family. He has 20 years of experience working as a farmer. He has been running his own farm since 1998. He cultivates all types of vegetables and fruits, according to the season. He uses plastic tents to grow his products. These tents allow him to better monitor product quality as well as grow his products for more months during the year. He works independently in his business. Today, he is requesting a loan of $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase needed supplies for his agricultural work. He estimates that the loan will help him increase his profits by 15%. 

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him (for example, blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his picture and not indicating his name and location). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese microfinance sector since 1999. Originally a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l., we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To purchase agricultural supplies

loans.name: Firuza

texts.en:
Firuza I. is 45 years old and married with four children. From the time Firuza was married, she has worked in the business of buying and selling cattle as well as breeding sheep. She canvases farms and several settlements in order to find and buy cattle at the lowest price. Her monthly income is about 200-250 AZN.

Firuza currently has three cows and one calf to fatten and sell. She has applied for a loan of 800 AZN to buy more calves and sheep.

loans.use: To buy more calves and sheep

loans.name: Narman

texts.en:
Narman A. is a 40-year-old trader who has sold products for the home and electrical goods for the last three years. He is married and has two children. 

He started his business with some savings and a year ago, he was able to build his own shop. His monthly income is about 250-350 Azerbaijani New Manat (AZN) and he is going to increase it to 500-600 AZN. Narman applied for a 900 AZN loan to increase the number of items he sells. He believes this loan will help him to improve the living conditions of his family.

loans.use: Purchase more items to sell

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen T. is currently in the business of selling bags of charcoal at the store around the market premises. She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  

Hellen is 29 years old and married to a driver. She has a child who does not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a house for rent.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Cirila

texts.en: Cirila C. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Tan-awan, Oslob, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a fish-vending business. Her husband Mariano C., who is 57 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living. They have five children who range from 16 to 29 years old. Cirila joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 10 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Cirila has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 16,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 7,200, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 11th loan, she is borrowing PHP 16,000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell so that she could continue to save up for the future and for an additional business. Cirila C. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. This picture was taken after the center meeting because the fish was delivered early in the morning to her buyers in the market. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team: http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Balisima Womens Group A-Lugazi

texts.en: Scovia N. operates a busy retail shop right in the middle of Lugazi Town. Her shop has been in existence for the last 5 years. It’s a business she began with savings from her small farming business. Scovia is a hardworking businesswoman and a happily married mother of four. In a month, she makes 450,000 shillings profit. With this loan, she wants to purchase more stock for her retail shop. She is looking to buy more sugar, rice, maize flour, soap and bread.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, rice, maize flour, soap and bread for resale

loans.name: Mercedesa

texts.en:
Mercedesa C. is a 31-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a fish-vending  business. She lives in Brgy. Tan-awan, Oslob, Cebu. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fish-vending  business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP4,000. 

Mercedesa is borrowing PHP 10,000 so that she  can purchase more inventory. This will be her sixth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP14,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Mercedesa aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

Photo was taken after she had sold her fish stock early in the morning. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon — a title of esteem bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase of more stock to sell

loans.name: Arzu

texts.en: Arzu A. is a 44-year-old  woman with two children. She has bred cattle for the last ten years. Poverty and lack of jobs pushed her to start her own business. As Arzu had previous experience working on a farm, her business has gone well and today, she has five cows. She also has enough room and fodder for even more cattle. So she decided to take a loan of 900 AZN and purchase more cattle and sheep. She wishes to increase her current income from 250 AZN to 500 AZN and the loan will allow her to do that. With her first loan from KIVA she was able to improve her business and recommended herself as a trust-worthy client of AqroInvest.

loans.use: purchase two cattle and four sheep

loans.name: Encarnación

texts.es:
La Sra. Encarnación D. 53 años D. edad, está felizmente casada con el Sr. Julio González quien se desempeña como taxista, juntos tienen 5 hijos ya mayores  tres D. ellos ya se independizaron y formaron sus respectivas familias y dos siguen viviendo con ellos.
DesD. muy joven se dedicó al comercio vendiendo ropas  y mercaderías por cuotas, y sobre pedidos muchos años años trabajó D. esa manera, hasta que le ha tocado una época D. crisis económica, en donD. se resentía la falta D. dinero que hizo que hasta el más puntual D. sus clientes no pudiera cumplir con sus compromisos, y eso le llegó a afectar también a ella.
Y como también le gusta la cocina pronto pensó en dedicarse a elaborar comidas y a realizar pedidos D. bocaditos tanto salados y dulces y así D. esa manera al cambiar D. rubro pudo seguir cumpliendo con puntualidad sus compromisos. Hoy día dice estar muy contenta porque a sus clientes les gusta los productos que hace.
Pero como hoy día hay que trabajar mucho para conseguir lo que uno quiere dice que otra vez le anexa los pedidos D. ropas a su micro empresa, pero ya sobre pedidos y dice que no pueD. quejarse y que le va muy bien.
Las veces que retira un crédito es un desafío para ella porque pueD. demostrar que trabajando se pueden lograr los objetivos y cumplir con los compromisos acordados en esta ocasión solicita el préstamo para la compra D. carnes, aceites, condimentos, verduras y ropas para volver a vender .
texts.en:
Encarnación is 53 years old. She is happily married to Julio González, who works as a taxi driver, and together they have 5 grown-up children; three of them live independently with their own families and the other two are still living with their parents. From an early age she started selling clothes and other goods in installments. She carried on like this for many years until the financial crisis, when the lack of cash maD. even the most reliable of her customers unable to fulfil their commitments. This eventually affected her as well. She also enjoys cooking so she thought that instead she could make food and take orders for sweet and savoury snacks. She changed career and so she was able to fulfil her commitments on time. She says she is happy now because her customers enjoy the food she makes. However, she explains that nowadays it is necessary to work very hard to achieve what one wants, so she has once again started to accept clothing orders through her small business. She says that so far she can't complain as things are going really well. Obtaining a loan is a challenge for her because she has the chance to show that by working hard it is possible to achieve her goals and fulfil any commitments maD.. She is requesting a loan to buy meat, oil, condiments, vegetables and clothes to start selling them again.

Translated from Spanish by Alba Sort , Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy raw materials such as meat, oil, condiments, vegetables and clothes to resell.

loans.name: Sabir

texts.en: Sabir Z. a very hard-working and responsible man. He is married, and to move his family ahead, he started his own business five years ago selling groceries in his neighborhood and taking advantage of the scarcity of shops nearby. With his first loan from AqroInvest, Sabir was able to increase the number of items he sells and now his monthly income is about 250-300 AZN. The cost of enlarging his store left him unable to afford to keep his business well stocked, which is why he is requesting a loan of 600 AZN to purchase merchandise.

loans.use: purchase more inventory

loans.name: Balisima Women's Group B-Lugazi

texts.en: N. Robinah is a likable, light-hearted and astute 45-year-old mother of five. For the last 5 years, she and her family have been subsisting on the monthly 200,000 shillings that she makes as profit in her retail shop. Lugazi is a cosmopolitan metropolis and her customers range from the poor to middle-class people and traders from other towns who come to do business. The basis of her success, she says, lies in hard work, a "never give up" attitude and courage in tackling challenges. She began this business with savings from the odd jobs she had done in and around Lugazi town. Because she had contact with so many successful business people, she thought that taking a shot at running a business would be a good proposition. With this loan, Robinah wants to buy more bags of rice, sugar, and maize flour to sell in her shop.

loans.use: The purchase of  more bags of rice, sugar, and maize flour to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 20-year-old single man living with his parents and seven siblings. He is still quite young, but he has proven to be a successful entrepreneur with his computer and games shop. He has owned and run this shop for more than three years. With his loan request of $800 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l., he will improve his business and purchase new computers at good prices and he needs this amount to add to his saving to buy them. Those computers will allow him to significantly increase his productivity and also his income. He is positive about his business prospects and plans to further expand. He is hoping to open a new branch of his shop in the coming year. 

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his picture, not indicating his name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages them to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen: Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese microfinance sector since 1999. Originally a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l., we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: purchase new computers

loans.name: Meshack

texts.en:
Meshack is 26 years old. He is married and has been blessed with 2 children, ages 4 and 2. His eldest child is currently attending school.

Meshack is a hardworking farmer from the town of Kisii in Western Kenya. He has been farming for the last 6 years. His main products are maize, beans, sugarcane, bananas, tea leaves and vegetables, which he sells to both Kenya Tea Development Authority and the local market. He also earns income from his masonry business.

Meshack has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 40,000 Kenyan Shillings to purchase a dairy cow. He plans to use the proceeds from this loan to open a workshop and educate his children. His primary challenges have been fluctuating weather patterns and disease, which affect his dairy animals.

In the future, he plans to open a big workshop and purchase several machines for use in that workshop. He appreciates all that Juhudi has brought him.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace W. is 35 years old and a married lady. Her husband is a contractor. They have three children aged six to sixteen years old. They hope to give their children a good education at the university level.

Grace's business is located in Isinya Town in Kitengela opposite the PCEA church. She owns a posho mill where she makes maize flour. She sells the flour to the people in the area, especially flower farm employees and other casual labourers. She has been involved in this business for the last four years. She says that this business is profitable. The only major challenge she has is the lack of enough flour to meet her customers' demands.

She is using her loan of Kes 80,000 to buy paper packages to pack the flour she makes to improve the service she provides to customers. In the future, she hopes to move to a better location and grow her business. She describes herself as welcoming and strict.

loans.use: To purchase paper packages for her flour-making business

loans.name: Jean Marie Vianney

texts.fr: H. Jean Marie Vianney est un homme de 50  ans qui a été à Kicukiro en province de la ville de Kigali, il vit actuellement en province de Kigali  district de Kicukiro, capital du Rwanda. Il est marié, il a trois enfants dont le plus âgée a 20 ans et le moins âgée a 3 deux  vont à l’école. Il est salarié dans une entreprise fabriquant les matériaux métalliques. Avec le prêt il veut réhabiliter  sa maison en achetant du sima, pierres pour fondation, portes et fenêtres. Les épargnes continuelles lui permettent de la survie de sa famille et il acheter une vache pour le lait des ses enfants, le reste il le vend pour augmenter les revenues et la capacité financière de la famille. Dans l’avenir il veut acheter une deux autres vaches pour devenir un grand éleveur en abandonnant le secteur des salaries et planifier pour le bon futur de  sa famille.
texts.en:
Jean Marie Vianney H. is a 50 year-old man who has lived in Kicukiro in the province of Kigali City. He now lives in the Kicukiro district of Kigali province, the capital of Rwanda. He is married and has three children. The oldest is 20 years old and the youngest is 3 years old. Two of the children go to school. He is an employee in a metal manufacturing company. He wants to renovate his house with the loan, buying sima, foundation stones, doors and windows. His continuous savings enable him to support his family and he will buy a cow to provide milk for his children. He will sell the rest of the milk to increase his income and the family's financial resources. In the future, he wants to buy two more cows and become a large breeder, leaving the wage-earning sector and planning for a better future for his family.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sima, doors, windows and foundation stones for his house

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is an active member and treasurer of Thoth Ber Group, which is being funded by Juhudi Kilimo. He has been practising mixed farming for 25 years and has employed one farmhand. His main products are maize, beans, nappier and bananas, which he sells at the local market. He also earns income from his rental houses in the same area.

David has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 45,000 Kenyan Shillings to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says with this loan he will be able to provide his family with enough milk for consumption, get enough manure for the crops - especially nappier - and sell milk, which will increase his income. His main challenge is the lack of organised markets and the unpredictable weather patterns. He hopes that his business will have improved in five years time and he will have acquired other dairy cows.

David is 52 years old. He is married and has been blessed with 10 children who are between the ages of 6 and 27. Six of the children are currently in school.

He is asking Juhudi to organize and empower farmers by teaching them better and improved farming methods. He is also grateful and hopes for more loans in future.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Caleb

texts.en:
Caleb is a hardworking farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya. He has been farming for over 50 years and has employed one farmhand. His farm produces maize, beans, tea leaves, bananas, milk and chicken, which he sells both at the local market and to the Kenya Tea Development Authority. He depends on the income from his farming activities to meet the needs of his family.

Caleb is 66 years old. He is married with 9 children, all of whom are adults. His youngest child is currently attending school.

Caleb has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 45,000 Kenyan Shillings to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that the income from this loan will help improve the living standards of his family. In his business, he faces the challenge of pests and disease, which affect his dairy production. Additionally, he is challenged by the high cost of farm inputs and the competition in the local market (the market is saturated), which leads to poor milk pricing.

In the future, he plans to expand his dairy farming and own a chuffcutter. He also plans to venture into poultry and goat farming.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Mehman

texts.en:
Mehman M. is 25 years old. He owns a grocery store where he sells different kinds of foodstuffs like macaroni, cookies, soft drinks, juices and tea. He also sells detergents. Mehman started this business a year ago with a small inventory of foodstuffs. Over time he expanded his business and now has become very successful.

Mehman is requesting a loan of 1,000 AZN to increase his stock. He is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices and push every once in a while to achieve his goal of becoming a successful entrepreneur.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase bales of secondhand clothes to sell

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret, 40, is married and has five children who are between the ages of 10 and 21, all attending school. Margaret has been operating her mixed farm in Kisii town, Western Kenya for over 20 years. Her farm produces maize, beans, tea leaves and vegetables which she sells to both the Kenya Tea Development Authority and the local market. She also earns income from her retail shop in the same area.

Margaret has requested this loan of 90,000 Kenyan Shillings from Juhudi Kilimo to expand her cereals business. She says that being a victim of post election violence, the proceeds from this loan will help her rebuild her life and even acquire a home for her family. She also hopes that the proceeds will help her pay school fees for her children. Margaret hopes to expand her cereals business to wholesale status in the future and also open various cereals stores and supply to schools. She is grateful to Juhudi for the loans since they have helped her get organized again.

loans.use: To expand her cereals business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more fish to fry to distribute to her increasing number of customers

loans.name: Zachary

texts.en:
Zachary O. is 35 years old and married with four children who are between the ages of 18 months and seven. Three of his children attend school. Zachary has a mixed farm in the town of Kisii in Western Kenya. He has been farming for fifteen years and employs one farmhand. His main products are eggs, milk, maize, beans and tea which he sells to both the local market and Kenya Tea Development Authority. He also operates a kiosk and a motorbike business in the same area.

Zachary has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 80,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. The proceeds from this loan will go towards the education of his children and the expansion of his business. His biggest challenges have been competition, price fluctuations which make his income unstable and pests and diseases which affect production.

Zachary plans to open a hardware store in the future. He says that ever since he became associated with Juhudi Kilimo it has helped him grow, and he really appreciates it.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Madelina

texts.en:
Madelina P. is 31 years old and married with a husband who is a manager. She has one child who does not go to school.

Madelina is currently in the business of selling fruit such as jackfruit, pineapples, oranges, passion fruit, etc. and is requesting a loan to stock more fruit such as pears and mangoes to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up an ice cream and juice shop.

loans.use: To stock more fruit such as pears and mangoes to sell

loans.name: Zamir

texts.en:
Zamir N. has always been a hard-working man who sells seasonal fruits and vegetables. He is married with one child. With a starting capital of 100 AZN and perseverance and dedication, he began this enterprise a year ago. He has expanded his business, and today his family helps him in the shop. He also breeds cattle, but his main financial source is his food shop. His monthly income is about 250-300 AZN, but he would like to increase that profit to 500 AZN.

Today he needs to buy additional produce to increase the variety of his shop’s offerings. For this purpose, Zamir is requesting a loan of 1000 AZN. He has already taken a loan from Aqroinvest and successfully completed it. He is ready to work even harder and make sacrifices to become a successful entrepreneur.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en: Erlinda S. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Tan-awan, Oslob, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a fish-vending business. Her husband Emiliano S., who is 52 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living. They have seven children who range from 6 to 31 years old. Erlinda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past six loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Erlinda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 17,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 7,200, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her seventh loan, she is borrowing PHP 17,000, which she intends to use as additional working capital so that she can continue to save up for their future and send her children to college. Erlinda S. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams.
