Reyna inicio su negocio en casa alquilada y hace 1 año construyo su casa a donde se mudo hace una semana, Reyna también alquila cuartos en su casa, lo cual le genera mas ingresos.
Reyna es socia del Banco Comunal Obreras y necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de una carreta para que inicie con la venta de salchipollos.
Los sueños de Reyna son construir el segundo piso de su casa para alquilar y que su hijo sea profesional.
texts.en:
Reyna is single, 33 years old, and has got a 12 year-old son that is in school. Reyna has a store in her house where she sells vegetables and general groceries. She began her business over 10 years ago, an activity that she realizes every day. Also, Reyna provides hemming services. She started her business in a rented house, but a year ago, she constructed her home which she moved into a week ago. Reyna also rents out rooms in her home in order to generate more income. She is a member of the Communal Bank Obreras and needs a loan of 1000 soles, which she would invest in the purchase of a cart so that she can begin selling salchipollos (a type of Peruvian hot dog). Reyna's dreams are to add a second floor to her house to rent out and for her son to become a professional.

Translated from Spanish by Tracy Quan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a cart.

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es:
Mercedes es casada, tiene 3 hijos que estudian, Mercedes tiene una panadería en su casa, su horno es rustico de leña, elabora panes típicos, sus productos los reparte a las tiendas de su barrio, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de personal por las noches. Además Mercedes tiene una tienda de abarrotes en su casa, hace algunos meses construyo el segundo piso de casa con ahorros y prestamos que obtuvo.
Mercedes es socia del Banco Comunal Obreras y solicita un préstamo de 1000 soles para la compra de leña.
Mercedes sueña son comprar maquinas para hacer todo tipo de panes.
texts.en:
Mercedes is married and has got 3 children that are in school. She has a bakery in her house and a rustic, wood-fire oven. She makes typical bread and then distributes her products to neighborhood stores, an activity that she accomplishes with help at night. In addition, Mercedes has a grocery store in her home. A few months ago, with savings and loans that she received, she added a second floor to her house. She is a member of the Communal Bank Obreras and is applying for a loan of 1000 soles to use towards the purchase of firewood. Mercedes dreams of buying machines so that she can make all different types of bread.

Translated from Spanish by Tracy Quan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase firewood.

loans.name: Reymunda Juliana

texts.es: Este cliente es originario del poblado de telica se dedica a la actividad de comercio venta de ropa, de manera ambulante, en la zona de mina el limón, donde tiene 12 años de estar viajando y donde su mercado ya lo tiene cautivo, es casada pero vive separada de su marido, bajo su cargo tiene 1 hija de 32 años y un nieto de 14 años, también convina otra actividad comercial en su casa como venta de pan y sopa los día domingo, y venta de ropa en su casa y el mismo poblado
texts.en:
This client is from the town of Telica. She sells clothes in an itinerant manner in the Mina El Limón area. She has been traveling there, where she has a captive market, for 12 years. She is married, but she lives separated from her husband. She has a 32 year old daughter and a 14 year old grandson under her care. She also has another commercial activity in her house. She sells bread and soup on Sundays, and she sells clothes in her house and her town.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pants for men, women, and children, blouses, sport shirts, skirts, men's t-shirts, sandals, boxers for men and women

loans.name: José Guadalupe

texts.es:
José Guadalupe Vázquez R. es un hombre muy trabajador que esta pendiente de la comodidad de su familia; es por ello que quiere terminar de construir un cuarto que con ahorros propios ha ido levantando pero en este momento el quiere un préstamo para comprar mas material y pagar mano de obra para su proyecto se realice.
José quedo viudo lo cual recibe pensión por sus 4 hijos y también el quedo deshabilitado lo cual no puede trabajar pero recibe su pago cada mes.
texts.en:
José Guadalupe V. R. is a hard-working man that is mindful of his family's comfort. Because of this he wants to finish the construction of a bedroom that he started with his own savings. At this time he would like a loan to buy more materials and to pay for labor to do the project. José is a widower and receives financial support for his 4 children since he is disabled and can't work. He receives his payment monthly.

Translated from Spanish by Ann Achilli, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase construction materials and to pay for labor

loans.name: Mujeres De Exito (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal Mujeres de Éxito está formado por 8 mujeres que viven en la ciudad de Cuenca, ciudad que es conocida por su rica cultura, la belleza de su centro histórico, su variada gastronomía y su gente hacen de esta una ciudad encantadora. Nuestras socias son mujeres que  luchan para mejorar la economía de sus  hogares y lo están logrando poco a poco con su sacrificio diario.

La Señora Raquel Esperanza B. vive por la ciudadela Jaime Roldós, es socia de la banca comunal hace 3años, los prestamos le han beneficiado tanto en su hogar como en su negocio, se dedica a la venta de ropa hace 7 años, cuenta con un puesto propio en el mercado de la feria libre  en la ciudad de Azogues, también vende su mercadería en su casa contando con una selecta clientela.
El  dinero de su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de más ropa y así surtir e incrementar su negocio.

Doña Raquel tiene 40 años, es casada y tiene 9 hijos de 21, 20, 18, 16, 13, 10, 8, 4 años de edad y su último hijo  tiene apenas 10 meses de nacido. Sus cuatro primeros hijos trabajan y le ayudan con la economía de su hogar, su quinto hijo  estudia en un colegio de la ciudad y sus dos últimos hijos estudian en la escuela, su esposo trabaja como empleado privado. Su meta es  comprarse un vehiculo para facilitar su trabajo.

La Señora. María Narcisa D. vive por el sector de Mayancela en la ciudad de Cuenca, tiene 44 años, es divorciada hace12 años y tiene 3 hijos de 26, 24 y 19 años de edad, todos sus hijos son casados y viven independientemente con sus familias, nuestra socia no tiene casa propia por lo que vive con una de sus hijas.
La Señora. María hace 6 años se dedica a la venta de todo tipo de ropa, vende todos los días recorriendo la ciudad, hace un año también se dedica a la venta de cosméticos de la marca Avon. Es socia hace 6 años de la banca comunal, pero por motivos de fuerza mayor ha tenido que salir por un tiempo y ahora se encuentra reingresando.  El dinero de su crédito lo va  a invertir en la compra de más ropa para tener surtida su mercadería, su meta es  llegar a tener un negocio más grande.
texts.en:
The communal bank Mujeres de Éxito (Successful Women) is made up of 8 women that live in the city of Cuenca, a city that is know for it rich culture, the beauty of its old town, its varied gastronomy and the people that make it a charming city. Our members are women that are working hard to improve their economic situations and little by little, with daily sacrifices, they are achieving this. Señora Raquel Esperanza B. lives in the Jaime Roldós residential area. She has been a member of the communal bank for 3 years. Her household, as well as her business, has benefited greatly from the loans. She has been selling clothing for a living for 7 years. She has a stall in the open market in the city of Azogues. She also sells her merchandise from her home to select customers. She will use the loan to buy more clothing in order to stock and increase her business. Doña Raquel is 40 years old. She is married and has 9 children, ages 21,20,18,16,13,10, 8, 4 and her last child is barely 10 months old. Her first four children work and help her with the household expenses. Her fifth child studies at an institute in the city and two of her younger children attend school. Her husband works as a private employee. Her goal is to buy herself a vehicle to make her job easier. Señora María Narcisa D. lives in the Mayancela sector in the city of Cuenca. She is 44 years old and has been divorced for 12 years. She has 3 children, ages 26,24 and 19. All of her children are married and live independently with their families. She doesn't have her own house so she lives with one of her daughters. Señora María has been selling all types of clothing for 6 years now. Everyday she travels around the city to sell her merchandise. A year ago she also started selling Avon cosmetics. She has been a member of the communal bank for 6 years, but because of circumstances she was compelled to leave for a time. She recently rejoined the group. She will use the loan to buy more clothing to stock more merchandise. Her goal is to have a much larger business.

Translated from Spanish by Ann Achilli, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more clothing such as pants, shirts, blouses, etc.

loans.name: Malumalusa

texts.en:
Malumalusa F. V. is 26 and married with no children.  She is starting a business venture, selling puletasi (Samoan formal wear).  Malumalusa needs a loan of WST 1000 to purchase additional fabrics & materials.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Malumalusa joined SPBD.  This is her 1st loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Malumalusa's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About  SPBD 

In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  

http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics & materials

loans.name: Paulia

texts.en:
Paulia T. is 39 and married with six children (ages 3 - 19).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Paulia has 2 years of experience in this business.  Paulia needs a loan of WST 1500 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 450 talas or US $188 per week) to improve/expand the business.

You can view pictures of a typical plantation in Samoa, taken by a Kiva Fellow, at:   http://picasaweb.google.com/agnes.p.chu/SamoanPlantation

In 2008, Paulia joined SPBD.    This is her 4th loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Paulia's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About  SPBD

In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  

http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Menime

texts.en:
Menime M. is 29 and married with three children (ages 1 - 14).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Menime has 4 years of experience in this business.  Menime needs a loan of WST 2200 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 450 talas or US $188 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2007, Menime joined SPBD.  This is her 4th loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Menime's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About  SPBD 

In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  

http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: José Ángel

texts.es:
José Ángel R.  y su esposa quieren dar a su único hijo un patrimonio con el cual en un futuro se pueda defender. Ellos cuentan con una vivienda que con ahorros fueron construyendo poco a poco; en la cual ahora desean construir una recamara mas para vivir cómodamente y dar a su hijo su propio espacio para cuando el crezca. 
José trabaja como almacenista en una maquiladora y su esposa para apoyarlo se dedica a la cuenta de ropa usada.
texts.en:
José Ángel R. and his wife want to give their only child assets with which he can make his way in the future. They have a house which they built little by little with savings. They want to build one more bedroom to live more comfortably and give their son more space for when he grows. Jose is a warehouse worker in a factory and his wife sells used clothing to help him.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction

loans.name: Juventino

texts.es: Juventino C. Hernández  y su esposa desean hacerle mejoras a su casita ya que es ahí donde vieron crecer a sus hijos. La casa necesita enjarre por dentro y por fuera pues las paredes ya están muy deterioradas por el tiempo, para poder realizar su proyecto ellos necesitan comprar material. Juventino todavía es apoyado por sus hijos que tienen trabajos muy buenos y el también trabaja para un maestro dando mantenimiento a su casa.
texts.en:
Juventino C. Hernández and his wife want to make improvements on their little house since it is there that they watched their children grow. The home needs plaster inside and outside. The walls have deteriorated over time. In order to do this project they need to buy material. Juventino is still supported by his children who have very good jobs and he also works for a builder maintaining his house.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To plaster the interior and exterior of the house

loans.name: Epenesa

texts.en:
Epenesa B. is 21 and married with two children (ages 1 and 5).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Epenesa has two years of experience in this business.  Epenesa needs a loan of WST 1500 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Epenesa joined SPBD.    This is her 2nd loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Epenesa's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About  SPBD 

In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  

http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Luz María

texts.es:
Luz María O. J. desde hace 10 años se dedica a la venta de ropa usada y zapatos en una pulga muy conocida en la ciudad donde le va muy bien con sus ventas.
Ella ha demostrado ser una mujer trabajadora que a pesar de la crisis no ha dejado su negocio, ya que es donde tiene ingresos para  mantener a sus 2 hijos los cuales están edad escolar. Luz María desea que se le apoye con capital para poder surtirse de mercancía para la temporada de frio y así estar preparada para el nuevo cambio climático.
texts.en:
Luz María O. J. has been selling second hand clothes and shoes in a well known flea market in the city for the last 10 years. Business is good. She has demonstrated that she is a hard working woman; in spite of the crisis she hasn't given up on her business, which provides her with an income to support her two children, both at school. Luz María would like help to raise the capital needed to stock up on merchandise for the cold season so as to be prepared for the change of weather.

Translated from Spanish by Alba Sort , Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock up the business.

loans.name: Ana María

texts.es:
Ana María es una madre de familia de 22 años de edad que vive junto a su esposo y a sus dos hijos de edad infantil en un sector urbano – marginal del distrito de Guadalupe, uno de los cinco distritos que conforman la provincia de Pacasmayo. Se encuentra ubicado en la región La Libertad, a una hora y quince minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo, capital de la región Lambayeque.

Se dedica desde hace un año a la venta de prendas de vestir y zapatos en un pequeño puesto de venta ubicado en su domicilio. Ella adquiere las prendas de vestir y los zapatos en la ciudad de Trujillo y luego los ofrece en venta a sus vecinos y conocidos. Ocasionalmente los vende al crédito.

Además se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza y cosméticos por catálogo, ella cuenta con un grupo de clientes que le compran sus productos con frecuencia, mientras más pedidos le realizan obtiene mas puntos de parte de la empresa que le provee los productos y por consiguiente obtiene mayores ganancias. 

Ana María utiliza los ingresos que percibe de estas actividades para apoyar a su esposo, que es chofer, en los gastos familiares, por su parte ella se esfuerza siempre por captar mas clientes y seguir manteniendo su negocio. Actualmente necesita incrementar su stock de productos comprando mas prendas de vestir para ampliar su nivel de ventas y percibir mayores ganancias. Para lograr su objetivo ha creído conveniente solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1200 nuevos soles.

Este préstamo le permitirá mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia con las ganancias que perciba a futuro, Ana María es una mujer responsable, empeñosa y muy trabajadora.
texts.en:
Ana María is a 22 year old mother who lives with her husband and two infant children in a marginalized urban area in the district of Guadalupe, one of five districts that make up Pacasmayo Province. This area is located in the region of La Libertad, an hour and 15 minutes away from the city of Chiclayo, the capital of Lambayeque region.

For the past year, Ana María has been selling clothing and shoes from a small sales stand located in her home. She wants to acquire clothing and shoes in the city of Trujillo and sell them later to her neighbors and acquaintances. Occasionally, she sells her merchandise on credit.

In addition, Ana María sells beauty products and cosmetics by catalog. She has a group of customers who buy products from her on a frequent basis. Ana María earns more points for her business as she places more orders. These points can be used to acquire products, which help her generate more income.

Ana María uses the income she generates from these activities to help her husband, who works as a chauffeur, with the family expenses. In the meantime, she continues to strive to attract more customers so that she can maintain her business. She currently needs to increase her inventory of products, so she plans to buy more clothing so that she can increase her sales and earn more money. To achieve this goal, Ana María has decided to request her first loan from Edpyme Alternativa in the amount of 1200 PEN.

This loan will allow her to improve her family’s quality of life using her future earnings. Ana María is a responsible, determined, and hardworking woman.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing & shoes

loans.name: Francisco Enrique

texts.es: Francisco tiene 55 años de edad, es casado tiene 3 hijos mayores de edad que trabajan de manera independiente, Se dedica a la brindar el servicio de taller de soldadura situado en su domicilio desde hace 35 años. El ofrece a sus clientes todo tipo de servicios en taller de soldadura y cada día se esmera por ofrecer un buen servicio. Francisco desea ampliar su negocio y comprar más productos de modo que pueda satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes y percibir mayores ganancias. Es por eso que solicita este financiamiento para la compra de maquinas de trabajo, herramientas, pinturas entre otras cosas.
texts.en:
Francisco is 55 years old, married, and has three adult children who work independently. He has been providing welding services out of a workshop in his home for the past 35 years. Francisco performs all types of welding jobs for his customers each day and strives to provide good service.

He wants to expand his business and buy more supplies so that he can meet the demand of his customers and generate more income. For this reason, Francisco is requesting a loan to buy machines, tools, paints, and other items he needs for his work.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase machines, tools, paints, and other items

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Restock her business

loans.name: Vicenta Del Socorro

texts.es: Vicenta del Socorro es mujer casada, tiene 60 años su actividad es una pequeña pulpería ubicada en su casa de habitación, en la cual vende granos básicos y otros artículos. Por lo que siempre ha disfruta de obtener financiamientos que son necesarios para el desarrollo de su negocio. Siempre está pensando en la forma de mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia. La inversión con este crédito será para la compra de granos básicos, golosinas, detergentes, leche y otros productos. Siempre sueña con obtener otro negocio para diversificar su experiencia.
texts.en:
Vicenta del Socorro is a married woman who is 60 years of age. She has a small store located in her home from which she sells basic grains and other products. As always, Vicenta enjoys obtaining loans which she needs to develop her business because she believes they will help improve her family’s quality of life.

This loan will be invested in the purchase of basic grains, candies, detergents, milk, and other products. She always dreams of starting another business so that she can diversify her experience.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase basic grains, candies, detergents, milk, and other products

loans.name: Karina Ruth

texts.es:
Karina tiene 26 años de edad, es soltera y vive junto a sus padres y hermanos en el caserio Rama Tepo, una zona rural del distrito de Mochumí, en la provincia de Lambayeque, ubicada a una hora de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica desde hace mas de un año a la venta de abarrotes en general en una bodega instalada en su domicilio. Este negocio es importante porque le brinda los ingresos necesarios para solventar sus gastos personales y apoyar al sostenimiento de su familia ya que, como su padre trabaja en la agricultura, necesitan de una actividad que les brinde recursos permanentes para poder salir adelante.

El negocio goza de mucha acogida gracias a la calidad de trato que ofrece y a que la bodega les provee de productos de consumo diario que no pueden obtener facilmente ya que la zona en donde viven se encuentra alejada del pueblo más cercano.

Karina desea ampliar su negocio para satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes,  por ello se encuentra solicitando a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la compra de abarrotes para lograr su objetivo.

Karina ya ha trabajado anteriormente con Nuestra Institución y con el fondo Kiva, ella se encuentra contenta ya que gracias al apoyo de Kiva su negocio ha podido avanzar. Karina es una joven responsable y que gusta mucho de la actividad que realiza. Sus vecinos y conocidos la consideran una persona de confianza.
texts.en:
Karina is 26 years old. She is single and lives with her parents and brothers in the Rama Tepo neighborhood, a rural zone located in the Mochumí district, within the Lambayeque province, one hour from the city of Chiclayo. She’s been selling groceries from a home-based store for more than one year. This is an important business because it brings in the income that she needs for her personal expenses and for supporting her family. Her father works in agriculture and they need a steady income in order to get ahead. The business attracts many customers, thanks to the service she provides and because the shop is stocked with daily food items that are not easily obtained within the zone; it is located far from the nearest town. Karina would like to expand her business to satisfy her customer demand, so she is requesting this loan of 1,000 PEN ($375) through Edpyme Alternativa. She will use the money to invest in more grocery items to meet her objective. Karina has worked with our institution, and Kiva’s backing, in the past. She is happy and, thanks to Kiva’s support, her business has been able to get ahead. Karina is a responsible young woman who enjoys her work very much. Her neighbors and acquaintances know her as a confident person.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Sarin's Group

texts.en:
Sorin C., 60, is the village bank president selected by the eight members of this group, located in Ta Hing village in Kandal province.  All members will use their portion of the loan for different purposes.

Sorin and his wife are farmers who own two hectares of land to cultivate rice, corn and peanut for a living.  With the farm, they work very hard to support their family.
 
Sorin will use the loan from AMK to build a lavatory for his family. This couple has four children, one is a musician and three are students.  They also support the farm.

loans.use: Build a lavatory for family use

loans.name: Chanthou's Group

texts.en:
Chantou C., 55, is the village bank president selected by the fourteen members of this group loan, located in Lvea Sa Leu village in Kandal province. Each member of this village will use their portion of the loan to support their different businesses.    

Chantou is a farmer who owns a 1.50-hectare piece of land to cultivate rice for a living.  She will use the loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide and to hire a worker to plow her farm to cultivate rice.  Chantou is also the teacher in the local school and her husband is a village chief.  

With their occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. This couple has five children, two are construction worker, one is a government worker and the other is a student.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer, pesticide and pay a laborer to plow her farm to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Demostenes

texts.en:
Demostenes T. is from the town of Talibon. He is 30 years old. Demostenes is single. To make a living, Demostenes owns & operates a fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes from operating a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish at the market. Demostenes has been engaged in his business for over 10 years. He is planning to grow hogs for fattening and sale. He says he works hard to save for his future family as he also plans to have his own family someday.

Demostenes joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Demostenes is requesting a loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. He also plans to buy piglets to start raising hogs. This will be the first loan taken out by Demostenes from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets, and piglets to start raising hogs

loans.name: Morn's Group

texts.en:
Morn S., 58, is the leader of this group loan having been selected by its five members who all live in Kaoh Chamroeun village in Kandal province. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their different businesses.

Morn and her husband are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice for a living.  They work very hard to support their family.  She wants a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide to cultivate rice.  They have a child who is a seamstress in a garment factory.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer and pesticide to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Ruby

texts.en:
Ruby D. C. is a married woman who lives in Narra Avenue, Narra, Palawan. She earns her living by operating three business ventures:   a general store, Avon and Natasha (beauty products & accessories) dealership and food vending businesses. Her husband Diosdado, who is 48 years old, works as a retailer to earn his living. 

Ruby joined NWTF-Project Dungganon because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 18 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ruby has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500 helped her increase her monthly profit to PHP 90,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 19th loan, she is borrowing PHP 50,000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock for her general store so that she can continue to save up for future expansion of her business. Ruby D. C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: more stock for her general store

loans.name: Vivena

texts.en:
Vivena D. is a married woman who lives in Paliya, Busogon, Bogo City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  fishing and general store businesses. Her husband Lalonde D., who is 41 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living.  They have 4 children who are 15 to  22 years old. 

Vivena joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 6 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Vivena has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5200,  uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 7th loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000, which she intends to use to purchase a new fishing boat so that she can continue to save up for future education for her children. Vivena D. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase new fishing boat

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Vuth's Group

texts.en:
Four people make up this group loan.  Vuth Veok, 41, is the leader of the group.  They all live in Kaoh Chamroeun village, in Kandal province.   They will use their portion of the loan for different purposes.

Vuth is a farmer who owns a plot of land that she uses to cultivate vegetable that are sold in the local market.  The business provides a small income to support the family. She has six children; one is a laborer while the others are students who support their parent's business.

loans.use: Buy more vegetable to support his wife business.

loans.name: Ratna Sari Group

texts.en:
Ni Putu A. is a 35-year-old woman living in the town of Melaya - Bali.  Ni Putu A. is the group leader of a 15-member group loan offered by MUK.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Ratna S. (PK-10256).

Ni Putu A. is married and has two school-aged children.  To make a living, Ni Putu A. owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale.  Ni Putu A. has been engaged in this business for over 4 years and earns approximately 250,000 IDR a month from these activities.

In 2008, Ni Putu A. joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Ni Putu A. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,400,000 IDR from MUK.  This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies.  She is now requesting a new loan of 1,400,000 IDR which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  This will be the 3rd loan taken out by the borrower from MUK.  Ni Putu A. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About MUK:

The mission of Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) is to assist small businesses in Bali by providing training, business consultation and loans thereby helping the owners and their families improve their everyday lives.

Ni Putu A. 0 (0) merupakan 35 tahun wanita.  Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota Melaya - Bali.  Ni Putu A. adalah pemimpin kelompok sebuah kelompok peminjam yang terdiri atas 15 anggota.  Meskipun setiap anggota kelompok menerima pinjaman perorangan, mereka semua bertanggung jawab untuk mengembalikan pinjaman rekan anggota kelompok mereka jika ada yang menunggak atau gagal membayar.  Nama resmi kelompok peminjam ini adalah Ratna S. (PK-10256).

Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual.  Ni Putu A. sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 4 tahun.  Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Ni Putu A. menghasilkan sekitar 250,000 IDR.  Dalam 2008, Ni Putu A. bergabung MUK untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan  -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis.  Ni Putu A. telah berhasil melunasi pinjaman sebelumnya sebesar 1,400,000 IDR dari MUK.  Pinjaman sebelumnya ini digunakan untuk membeli pakan ternak & pasokan lain.  Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 1,400,000 IDR.

Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 3rd pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari MUK.

Tentang MUK:

Misi Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) adalah untuk membantu usaha kecil di Bali dengan memberikan perlatihan, konsultasi bisnis, dan pinjaman uang, dengan demikian membantu pemilik usaha dan keluarga mereka memperbaiki hidup sehari-hari.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Gertrudes

texts.en:
Gertrudes I. is from the town of Talibon. She is 35 years old. Gertrudes is married and has five school-aged children. She is involved in fishing and has been catching and selling fish for more than a few years now. Her husband is also a fisherman. Gertrudes wants to have their own fishing boat so they would have more catch she could sell at the market. 

Gertrudes joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gertrudes is requesting a loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase a fishing boat. This will be the first loan taken out by Gertrudes from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase a fishing boat

loans.name: Menchie

texts.en:
Menchie L. is a married woman who lives in Rizal St., Brgy. Zone 9, Talisay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  general store and E-load dealer businesses. Her husband, Erwin L., who is 46 years old, is a Chief Security Officer, and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have three children who are 11 to  17 years old. 

Menchie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 6 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Menchie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 20,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 28,000,  uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 7th loan, she is again borrowing PHP 20,000, which she intends to use to buy more stock for her general store so that she can continue to save up for the future education of their children. Menchie L. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
This is Angela E., a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Eric E., a tricycle (three-wheeled public transport) driver. They are blessed in their marriage with good health and strong physiques which enable them to work hard for their future together, for themselves and for their family.

Angela operates a variety store which sells not only the usual groceries, toiletries and drinks. She also added school supplies to her business inventory so that her customers would no longer have to trek up to a bookstore to buy their needs. Her variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Angela earns her profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Angela’s store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 250 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 8,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries, beverages and school supplies to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Angela dreams of being able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have a new business like an internet café, someday.

loans.use: buy groceries, beverages, and school supplies for resale

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma K. is a 55-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures:  hog raising and fishing businesses. She lives in, Brgy. Patao, Bantayan, Cebu City. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her hog raising and fishing businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 5200 from her business activities.

 Elma is now borrowing PHP 29,000 so that she  can  purchase feed and vitamins for the pigs that she is raising. This will be her 14th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 25,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Elma aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase of feed and vitamins for pigs

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Mrs. Chea N. is a long-time businesswoman and a low-income person. She has been operating a grocery business since the beginning of 2005. In front of her home, she owns a kiosk where she sells different kinds of materials, including cooking ingredients, cleaning products and some snack foods, to people in her village. Chea N. is married to 52-year-old Cheng Taiy, who is a fish-raiser. The couple is blessed with six children, two of whom are now married. In order to earn extra profits and to make the business more successful, Chea N. will be using the loan she requested to increase her inventory. (Mrs. Chea N.'s husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To increase her inventory.

loans.name: Ma.gina

texts.en:
Ma. Gina R. is a 39 year old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures: farming, a general store and hog fattening. She lives in Prk. 3, Brgy. Inalad, Siaton, Negros Oriental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her farming, general store and hog fattening businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 9500. Ma. Gina is now borrowing PHP 26000 to fund her farming activities. This will be her 17th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 25000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Ma. Gina aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund farming operations.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria H. is from the town of Talibon. She is 54 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Gloria owns and operates a business venture in the food sector operating a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling dried fish to the community. She hopes to grow her business and for it to provide her with a stable income.

Gloria joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Gloria is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to dry and sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell.

loans.name: Sinuon's Group

texts.en:
Sinuon B. is 55 years old and the village bank president, having been selected by its sixteen members.  They all live in Tuol Kdei village, in Kandal province.  The members will use the loA. to support their different businesses.

Sinuon and her husband are farmers who own a 3.50-hectares piece of land to cultivate rice, peanut and cucumber for a living.  They are also fishermen. With both of these occupations, they earn a small income to support their family.  For the fishing business, Sinuon will use the loA. to buy a fishing boat and a machine for fishing.  They have two children, a farmer and a student.

loans.use: Buy fishing boat and fishing machine for fishing.

loans.name: Kuña Guapa Group

texts.es:
Para la formación el presente comité inicio la Señora Maria Dávalos quien está domiciliada en el barrio San Miguel de Ciudad del Este. Ella Contacto con sus vecinas y amigas para formar el comité en su comunidad.
El comité se Denomina Kuña Guapa  están en el Décimo Ciclo   con 20  integrantes, es un grupo que se destaca  en el barrio por ser muy unidas solidarias  y responsable entre ellas.
Maria se dedica a la venta de ropas en forma ambulante, recorriendo varias localidades del país para vender sus ropas. 
Además de ropas ella también vende calzados deportivos y sabanas.
En ocasiones ella deja sus mercaderías a crédito y luego pasa a cobrarlos, comente que la actividad es muy sacrificada pero que le ayuda a su familia especialmente con la alimentación diaria.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de ropas como remeras, camisas, suéter, pantalones, buzos y otros.
Agradece a la Fundación Paraguaya y a los KIVA por la ayuda crediticia.
texts.en:
In forming this group, the main contact was Maria Dávalos, who lives in the Barrio San Miguel neighborhood of Ciudad del Este. She contacted her neighbors and friends to form the communal bank in her community. The communal bank is called Kuña Guapa. There are 20 members, and they are in their tenth cycle. The group stands out in the neighborhood for being united, supportive, and responsible with each other. Maria sells clothes in an itinerant manner. She goes to different locations in the country to sell her clothes. In addition to selling clothes, she sells athletic shoes and sheets. Sometimes she sells her merchandise on credit, and later she goes to collect. She says that this activity is very demanding, but it helps her family, especially with the daily food. She is requesting a loan to buy clothes like t-shirts, shirts, sweaters, pants, sweatshirts, and others. She is grateful to the Fundación Paraguaya and Kiva for the financial help.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothes like t-shirts, shirts, sweaters, pants, sweatshirts, and others

loans.name: Jesselyn

texts.en: Jesselyn T. is from the town of Talibon. She is 35 years old. Jesselyn is married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, Jesselyn runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for more than 18 years now. Her husband is a fisherman and she helps him sell his catch to their community. She also hopes for her husband's fishing business to grow. Jesselyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jesselyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell and to buy fishing equipment. This will be the first loan taken out by Jesselyn from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business and the living conditions of her family. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also offers savings, insurance and training programs through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell and fishing equipment

loans.name: Tserendulam

texts.en:
Ms. Tserendulam, 37, is single mother and lives with her three boys in her elder brother's house in Ulaanbaatar city. She used to work for the Temuujin Mench clothing factory as a tailor until the factory was shut down.

In 2004, she bought two sewing machines and started her own tailoring business. Now she has six sewing machines, employs two tailors and sells her products to three different companies by contract. Her current assets are 870,000 Mongolian tugriks. 

Recently, she bought a piece of land but has no house on it. Therefore, she and her children live temporarily in her brother's house. She is a very hardworking woman with a strong will. Her eldest son Baasanbat dreams to become a mathematician. 

She is planning to extend her business and profits and therefore improve her lifestyle and give her children a good education. She is planning to use this loan for her business extension, increasing her current assets and buying some fabric and materials for her tailoring business.

loans.use: Increasing her current assets and buying some fabric and materials

loans.name: Xiomara

texts.es:
la sra. Xiomara C. se dedica al comercio, cuenta con una tienda de venta de Medicina popular denominada VARIEDADES IVETH, Ubicada en El Barrio El Centro frente al parque central contiguo a comedor Emmanuel, La sra. Xiomara C. tiene más de 5 años de realizar esta actividad económica lo que le hace tener experiencia en el manejo de su negocio. Xiomara es una mujer muy conocida en el lugar por su espíritu de superación, solvencia moral y de buena conducta, se ha sabido ganar la clientela lo que le ha generado mayor demanda en su negocio.
Las ventas las realiza de contado y al crédito generándole de esta forma clientes durante todo el año.
el credito lo utilizara para comprar mas medicamentos para tener mas surtido su negocio y así brindarle a sus clientes un mejor servicio ademas venderles mas medicamentos y otros productos.
texts.en:
Xiomara C. is a merchant. She has a store, Variedades Iveth, where she sells popular medicine. The store is located in the El Centro neighborhood in front of the central park and adjacent to the Emmanuel restaurant. She has been doing this for five years, which gives her experience in managing her business. Xiormara is a woman who is well known in her area for her spirit for improvement and her good character. She has known how to win customers, which has generated a greater demand in her business. She sells for cash and for credit, which generates customers throughout the year. She will use the loan to buy more medicines in order for her business to be better stocked. That way she will provide her customers with better service and sell them more medicines and other products.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy medications

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Tam

texts.en:
Selling fresh fish is the main part of 50-year-old Tam L.'s daily activities, from which she earns a living. (Note: Mrs. Tam L. was not available at that day, so her husband is pictured instead.) Mrs. Tam L. sells fish she gets from her bulk supplier. She receives help for transporting fish to the market from her husband, and additionally, her husband takes time to run a motor-taxi service. 

The couple lives with seven children, while another one is already married and has started a new home. Tam L. is running her business well because she has skills in public relations, which she uses with her customers. However, her income is not very much as her business has come to a low capacity due to insufficient financial capital. Tam L. wishes to have more money to increase her capital, which will allow her to improve her profits. This is why she has decided to ask for a Kiva loan.

loans.use: To increase her capital

loans.name: Sin's Group

texts.en:
Sin H., age 42, is the village bank president, having been selected by its seventeen members.  They all live in Tuol Kdei village, Kandal province.  With this loan, each member hopes to increase his or her income and standard of living.

Sin and her husband are farmers who own a plot of land that they use to cultivate rice, peanut and taro.  They work very hard to support their family.  Sin will use this loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer and pesticide to support her crop.  They have three children, one is a security guard in a hotel and the other two are students.

loans.use: Buy rice seed, fertilizer and pesticide to support her farming crop

loans.name: Daya Pertiwi Group

texts.en: Gusti Ayu S. is a 32-year-old female living in the town of Melaya, Bali. She is the group leader of this 15-member group loan offered by MUK. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Daya Pertiwi (PK-10262). Gusti Ayu S. is married and has two school-aged children. She owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over four years and earns approximately 300,000 IDR a month. In 2010, Gusti Ayu S. joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,700,000 IDR from MUK. This previous loan was used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. Gusti Ayu S. is now requesting a new loan of 1,800,000 IDR which will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. The loan will be her 2nd from MUK. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About MUK: The mission of Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) is to assist small businesses in Bali by providing training, business consultation and loans thereby helping the owners and their families improve their everyday lives. ***************************************************** Gusti Ayu S. 0 (0) merupakan 32 tahun wanita. Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota Melaya - Bali. Gusti Ayu S. adalah pemimpin kelompok sebuah kelompok peminjam yang terdiri atas 15 anggota. Meskipun setiap anggota kelompok menerima pinjaman perorangan, mereka semua bertanggung jawab untuk mengembalikan pinjaman rekan anggota kelompok mereka jika ada yang menunggak atau gagal membayar. Nama resmi kelompok peminjam ini adalah Daya Pertiwi (PK-10262). Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual. Gusti Ayu S. sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 4 tahun. Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Gusti Ayu S. menghasilkan sekitar 300,000 IDR. Dalam 2010, Gusti Ayu S. bergabung MUK untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis. Gusti Ayu S. telah berhasil melunasi pinjaman sebelumnya sebesar 1,700,000 IDR dari MUK. Pinjaman sebelumnya ini digunakan untuk membeli bibit ternak untuk dibesarkan & dijual di masa mendatang. Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 1,800,000 IDR. Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 2nd pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari MUK. Tentang MUK: Misi Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) adalah untuk membantu usaha kecil di Bali dengan memberikan perlatihan, konsultasi bisnis, dan pinjaman uang, dengan demikian membantu pemilik usaha dan keluarga mereka memperbaiki hidup sehari-hari.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies

loans.name: Shahnaz's Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz is a wife of M. E. and lives in the Pakistani city of Multan, famous for its shrines and sweetmeats. She owns a small two-roomed house there where she has lived with her family for over eight years. Shahnaz is a mother of four children – one daughter and three sons. Her eldest son is in second grade and her daughter is in kindergarten. The other two children are not yet of school age.
Shahnaz operates an embroidery business from her house. She collects orders from different boutiques and clothes shops and earns an income by fulfilling them. She charges approximately 1500 PKR for each embroidered dress and she completes five dresses per month, which enables her to generate 7500 PKR per month. Her income has become a great financial source for her family.
Shahnaz's husband is a driver. He drives a local 32-seater bus for up to eight hours a day. He usually starts driving at 6am and returns home at 1pm. His work requires much effort and that is why Shahnaz pays complete attention to her husband's diet and sleep. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband. With the loan, he will repair his bus because its engine is creating problems and its seat covers have become rough, which creates a bad impression to the passengers.
Shahnaz is on her third loan and has proved to be a responsible borrower from Asasah. For previous loans, she paid her installments on time and never missed a meeting.

loans.use: To repair her husband's bus and change the seat covers

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta S. is from the town of Talibon. She is 38 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Julieta owns and operates a fishing business, using a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish to the market. Julieta is thankful for her business because she is able to provide for her family and sustain her children's education.
Julieta joined Kiva partner, CEVI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. This loan will be her first from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets

loans.name: Santos Eucebia

texts.es:
la sra. Santos Eucebia G. C. cuenta con una tienda en la cual vende Ropa nueva, cosméticos, productos para niños como leches en polvo, desodorantes, talcos, cremas, unguentos.  su tienda opera bajo el nombre de "VARIEDADES CHEVITA”.

las ventas las hace de contado y crédito lo que le permite tener clientes permanentes durante todo el año.

la sra. Santos G. tiene 8 años de dedicarse a este tipo de actividad y se ve que le ha ido muy bien, ya que con los ingresos que su negocio le a generado a salido adelante.
Santos apoya a sus padres en lo necesario para la casa ya que por los momentos esta soltera y no tiene hijos.
Santos se esta preparando para cuando se case tener su negocio bien establecido.
 
el credito lo utilizara para la compra de mas mercadería como ser ropa interior, ropa casual y cosméticos, 
Desea satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes.
Chevita como popularmente se le conoce es una mujer muy luchadora y de muy buenas costumbres.
texts.en:
Santos Eucebia G. C. has a store where she sells new clothes, cosmetics, products for children like powdered milk, deodorants, talcum powder, creams, and ointments. Her store operates under the name Variedades Chevita. She sells for cash and for credit, which generates customers throughout the year. Santos G. has been doing this type of activity for eight years. It is going very well for her. She has been able to get ahead with the income that her store has generated. Santos helps her parents with the home necessities. She is single and does not have children. Santos is preparing to have her business well established for when she gets married. She will use the loan to buy more merchandise like underwear, casual clothes, and cosmetics. She wishes to satisfy her customer demand. Chevita, as she is called, is a very tenacious woman with very good moral values.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy powdered milk, sanitary napkins, toilet paper, talcom powder, deodorants, creams, ointment, soap, nail polish, clothes, and cosmetics

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia I. is from the town of Talibon. She is 55 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Lydia owns and operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. She also spends time selling fish to the community as her husband is a fisherman. She also dries fish sometimes and displays them in her store.
Lydia joined Kiva partner, CEVI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products for resale and fishing equipment. This loan will be her first from CEVI. Lydia plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
This is Teresita B., 45, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Fernando B., a technician, and is also a stay-at-home mother who manages the household while she attends to her business.
Teresita operates a photocopying business. She now finds that there is more need for her services now than previously as customer demand has increased. Her main customers are students, who require her services for their school work. She also has customers who require photocopying for documents, form replication and so forth. Her regular customers are students from the school near her business site and members of the local community. Teresita earns a minimum of 300 PHP profit every day.
To help her continue to operate her business, Teresita is requesting a 20,000 PHP loan. She will use the loan to buy bond paper, toners and ink, and other supplies for her business. She will also invest a portion of the loan to buy spare parts and pay repair fees for her photocopying machine. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
Teresita dreams of being able to give her all her children a good, high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy bond paper, toners and ink, and other supplies for her business

loans.name: Sofia's Group

texts.en:
Sofia is 21 years old, married, and has one son. She owns a small, two-roomed house where she has lived with her family for over five years. Her house is situated in the Pakistani city of Multan, famous for its shrines and sweetmeats.
Sofia is a very talented lady. She owns and operates a sewing business in order to share the financial burden with her husband. She is good at her art and gets regular orders from her neighbors. She earns approximately 3,500 to 4,000 PKR from her work, which enables her to pay for the utilities.
Sofia's husband is A. M.. He runs a scrap shop in the market where he deals with rough and old items, such as wooden cupboards, book shelves etc. He has been doing this work for over four years. Sofia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband. With the loan, he will buy scrap for his scrap business and increases his profit on it. Sofia is on her second loan and has proved to be a responsible borrower during her previous loan term.
Note: In this photo, one of the group members, Shazia Perveen, is showing her sewing business.

loans.use: To purchase scrap for her husband's business

loans.name: Maria Magdalena

texts.es:
la sra. Maria Magdalena González se dedica a la venta de golosinas, cuenta con un Comedor que opera bajo el nombre de Comedor Emmanuel.
este negocio le ha sido de gran bendición ya que a través de el logro darles el estudio y crianza a sus hijos.
Maria a temprana edad enviudo tornándose mas difícil la situación, pero a pesar de todo Maria se a esforzado para salir adelante hoy en día le da gracias a Dios.
doña Nena como se le conoce en la zona dice que ella fue la primera que estableció un comedor en la zona y que para ese tiempo solo tenia un costo de 0.75 centavos El plato, el buen uso y la buena administración le han permitido salir adelante pues ha logrado comprar y realizarle mejoras a su casa ya que uno de sus sueños es construir un Hospedaje y así brindarle una mejor atención a las personas que llegan de visita al municipio.
texts.en:
Maria sells meals from a food stall she operates under the name 'Comedor Emmanuel'. The business has been a great blessing and enabled her to raise and educate her children. Maria became a widow at an early age, making her situation worse. But in spite of everything, Maria has struggled to get ahead. Today, she gives thanks to God. Maria, or “Doña Nena” as she is known locally, says she was the first to establish a kitchen stall in the zone and that at present, her costs are only 75 centavos (in Lempiras) per plate. Efficiency and good administration have permitted her to get ahead. Maria has been able to buy a house and make home improvements. One of her dreams is to construct an inn and thus, offer better service to people who come to visit the municipality.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING FLOUR (CORN AND WHEAT), BEANS, MEAT, VEGETABLES, LARD, OIL, CONDIMENTS, SALSAS, EGGS, BREAD, COFFEE, SOFT DRINKS, AND JUICES

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Oeun's Group

texts.en:
Oeun R., 61, is the village bank president, havI. been selected by its fifteen members, who are located in Tuol Kdei village, Kandal province.  With this loan, each member hopes to increase his or her income and standard of livI..

Oeun sells fish in the local market and is able to earn a small income to support her family.  Her house is old and needs to be fixed.  She is requestI. a loan to fix her house.  Oeun R. is a widow with one child who works in a bakery shop.

loans.use: Fix house.

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Mrs. Kong S. is employed as a staff member in her community and has had her job since before she was married. She is now married with seven children, one of whom has ready got married and the other six are single. Almost all of her children have jobs and provide their small income to meet any needs of their family. She has a life partner in her husband who owns a car that he uses to provide a taxi service.

One of Kong S.’s daughters currently sells a few grocery items but her business has come to a low capacity due to insufficient financial capital. Therefore, Kong S. is taking out her loan for her daughter to use to increase her capital which will allow her to improve her profit.

loans.use: To increase the capital of her daughter's grocery business

loans.name: Zarina's Group

texts.en:
Zarina is a 44-year-old married woman who lives in a city called Multan, Pakistan, famous for its shrines and sweetmeats. She owns a small house of two rooms where she lives with her seven children and her husband of over 20 years.

Zarina has five sons and two daughters: her elder son has a timber-selling business; next to him is a painter who paints walls and windows on call; the next two work in a factory on monthly wages; the youngest of her sons is free and doesn’t do anything; her daughters stay at home and help their mother in managing the household chores.

Zarina’s husband is named N. M. and he has a job in the government sector as a security guard but earns a low income.

Zarina herself owns and operates her sewing business. She does this work to share the financial burden of her husband and to make him relax from this aspect. Her care for him makes her unique and he respects her a lot.

Zarina has applied for a loan from Asasah for her elder son. With the loan, he will buy timber in bulk and increase his sales by selling to more customers. Zarina is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan.

loans.use: To purchase more timbers for her son's timber-selling business

loans.name: Otgonbat

texts.en:
Mr. Otgonbat is 30 years old and lives with wife and two kids in a Mongolian traditional nomadic tent in Ulaanbaatar city. His son, Tengis, 7, attends a secondary school and his daughter, Temuulen, 2, goes to kindergarten. Otgonbat’s wife Narantuya works in local kindergarten number 87 as a teacher. Otgonbat has been running his taxi business for eight years and his profit is quite stable.

In 2005 they obtained a license for their piece of land on which they are living at the moment. Their plan is to build a house on their land. The reason they asking for this loan is that they want to buy some building materials and start the building project.

loans.use: To buy some building materials to start his building project

loans.name: Maria Del Carmen

texts.es: la sra. Maria del Carmen M.  se dedica al comercio cuenta con una tienda que opera bajo el nombre de pulperia MARYCARMEN y esta ubicada en su casa de habitación en el barrio Las Flores de la ciudad de El Paraíso, cuenta con mas de 6 años de experiencia en el manejo de su negocio, Maria lo administra personalmente y durante todo este tiempo le ha ido muy bien pues nos comentaba que del negocio paga los gastos familiares y compromisos adquiridos, a la vez cuenta con 2 manzanas de finca de café cosechero permitiéndole tener otras fuentes de ingresos. El credito lo utilizara para surtir mejor su negocio y que sus ventas sean mejores para poder mejorar sus condiciones de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Maria del Carmen is a merchant who has a general store, operating under the name 'Pulpería MARYCARMEN'. It is located in her house in Las Flores (The Flowers) barrio, in the city of El Paraíso (The Paradise). She has more than 6 years of experience in running her business. Maria administers it personally and during all this time, things have gone well. She comments that the business pays for the family's expenses and obligations. At the same time, Maria has a farm with 3 ½ acres of coffee that can be harvested, giving her an added source of income. The loan will be used to better supply the business, increasing sales and improving the conditions of life for Maria and her family.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING CREAMS, SHAMPOOS, HAIR CONDITIONERS, SOFT DRINKS, TOILET PAPER, SANITARY NAPKINS, SOAPS, BATTERIES, CANDLES, HAIR GEL, Q-TIPS, NAIL POLISH, DEODORANTS, BREAD, TOOTH PASTE, RAZORS, ETC

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Dionesia

texts.en:
This is Dionesia A., 39, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She has two children, both of whom are still in high school. At this time, she is working hard to send both of them to college, a dream for most poor Filipino parents like Dionesia as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Dionesia maintains a direct-selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customers order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalog, and these discounts are the profits that dealers are receiving as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 2,300 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, Dionesia is requesting a Php 18,000 loan that she will use to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Dionesa dreams of being able to give all her children a good and high-quality education through all her hard work in her business.

loans.use: To buy orders for her customers

loans.name: Mary Marden

texts.en:
Mary Marden N. is from the town of Talibon. She is 39 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Marden owns and operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Sometimes, she helps her husband gather seaweed, which they sell to the market.
Mary Marden joined Kiva partner, CEVI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell and buy equipment for gathering seaweed. This loan will be her first from CEVI. Mary Marden plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase products to sell in her store and equipment for gathering seaweed

loans.name: Kuña Guapa 2 Group

texts.es:
El comité se Denomina “Kuña Guapa 2” están en el Décimo Tercer  
Ciclo   con 16  integrantes, es un grupo que se destaca  en el barrio por ser muy unidas solidarias  y responsable entre ellas.
Todas trabajan unidas realizando trabajos en conjunto para recuadar fondos y de esa manera pagar las cuotas del prestamo.  
La señora florentina R. es una señora trabajadora y se dedica  a la venta de producto de uso domestico.
Este negocio es muy importante para ella ya que ayuda a su familia con lo que vende en su despensa.
Desea aumentar las mercaderías que tiene su despensa para ello solicita el préstamo para la compra de fideos, arroz, azúcar, aceite, y otros.
texts.en:
This group is called "Kuña Guapa 2” and is in its 10th loan cycle. The group has 16 members, and is known in the neighborhood as a group of responsible individuals with a strong sense of solidarity. All of the members work together to generate funds and in this way make the payments on their loan. Florentina R. is a hardworking woman who sells domestic products. This business is very important to her, because she helps her family with the sales from her store. She would like to increase the merchandise she has in her store, and to do this she requests a loan to buy noodles, rice, sugar, cooking oil, and other items.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy noodles, sugar, flour, rice and other items
